headline: Japan Plans $51 Billion in Stimulus to Economy
abstract: Japan announced a stimulus package on Thursday that includes $51 billion to help households and businesses, the boldest of several measures that officials took to try to stanch the global credit crisis, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener said.

headline: Analyst Widens Predicted Loss for Citigroup
abstract: Veteran banking analyst Richard Bove widened his fourth-quarter loss estimate for Citigroup , saying the bank may take sizable write-downs in its capital-markets operations, similar to those seen in Goldman Sachs ‘s and Morgan Stanley‘s fourth-quarter results.

headline: Insider to Head Calpers
abstract: The nation’s largest pension fund, the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, named an investment strategist, Anne Stausboll, as its chief executive on Wednesday.

headline: Lawyer’s Arrest in Canada Leaves His Firm in Chaos
abstract: Marc Stuart Dreier, a high-living New York lawyer who has a gaggle of celebrity clients and a large firm that bears his name, was released from a Canadian jail on Friday after promising to return to court to face charges that he impersonated another lawyer on Tuesday at the offices of a large Canadian pension fund, The New York Times’s Alison Leigh Cowan and William K. Rashbaum reported.

headline: Wachovia Posts $23.9 Billion 3rd-Quarter Loss
abstract: Wachovia reported a $23.9 billion net loss for its third quarter, as the struggling bank took nearly $19 billion in goodwill impairment and $6.6 billion in charges related to potential losses on its troublesome mortgages.

headline: Tesla Promised Another $40 Million, Loses Lawsuit
abstract: The electric car start-up says investors have committed $40 million to help the company out of its financial trouble.

headline: MySpace and MTV Turn Pirated Video Into Ad Dollars
abstract: MySpace says it will begin selling ads against some television clips on its site, even if they are pirated.

headline: Credit Suisse Expands Its Business in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

headline: We Made Mistakes, Fed Chairman Says
abstract: “I and others were mistaken early on in saying that the subprime crisis would be contained.”

headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai
abstract: FountainVest Partners, a China-focused private equity fund, was officially launched in Shanghai late last week.

headline: Pershing Puts Target Back in Its Sights
abstract: What does William Ackman have in store for Target?

headline: Parsing the Mystery Foundry Press Release
abstract: Foundry Networks announced on Friday that it had adjourned its shareholder meeting from that day until Oct. 29 because of “recent developments related to” its proposed merger with Brocade Communications. This stunning and ominous disclosure, coupled with no clarifying statement, promptly resulted in a 25.7 percent drop in Foundry’s stock price.

headline: Fury Builds Over Crisis at Banks
abstract: The Wall Street backlash is under way and if it grows strong enough, it could end with some bankers facing criminal trials, The New York Times’s Floyd Norris writes.

headline: Patricof Takes On ‘Doom and Gloom’
abstract: Alan Patricof, the venture capitalist, seems to have has a bone to pick with his rivals over at Sequoia Partners and the bloggers who love to cover them.

headline: Lazard’s 3rd-Quarter Profits Fall 34%
abstract: Lazard said on Wednesday that its third-quarter profit fell 34 percent, as the investment bank took charges on buying back the parts of its asset-management business it did not already own, as well as the market turmoil and the collapse of Lehman Brothers.

headline: The Flip Videocam: Best Gadget of 2008?
abstract: The Flip MinoHD is on track to become the best-selling gadget of the holiday season. Here’s why.

headline: Barclays Seeks Infusion from Russian Banks, Report Says
abstract: British bank Barclays is seeking investment from Russian state-owned banks Sberbank and VTB , The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Member of a Panel Overseeing the Financial Bailout Objects to Its Findings
abstract: The lone Republican on a Congressional panel overseeing the $700 billion financial rescue plan has voted against its first advisory report, setting up a possible partisan rift as it is delivered to lawmakers on Wednesday, The New York Times’s Diana B. Henriques reported.

headline: S.E.C. Issues Rules on Conflicts in Credit Rating
abstract: Federal regulators on Wednesday adopted new rules designed to stem conflicts of interest and provide more transparency for Wall Street’s credit-rating industry, widely faulted for its role in the subprime mortgage debacle and ensuing credit crisis.

headline: Credit Squeeze Tightens Bind on AT&T
abstract: The tightening of the global credit markets is crimping the world’s largest telecommunications company, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Synacor Pulls the Plug on I.P.O.
abstract: Synacor, which designs Internet portals and offers aggregation services, put the kibosh on its planned initial public offering Tuesday, as the I.P.O. market remains comatose. The company cited unfavorable market conditions.

headline: Like J.P. Morgan, Warren Buffett Braves a Crisis
abstract: In the midst of a financial crisis, a towering figure of American business steps forward with his reputation and financial resources for public good and personal gain.

headline: Pardon Who?
abstract: Do any business executives deserve pardons?

headline: Ryan Says Treasury Borrowing Needs ‘Unprecedented’
abstract: The U.S. Treasury Department faces huge borrowing needs this year to finance multiple programs the government is running to try to restore stability to severely strained markets, a top U.S. Treasury official said Tuesday.

headline: Freescale Considers Options for Cellphone Chip Unit
abstract: Freescale Semiconductor said on Thursday it was exploring strategic options for its cellphone chip business and intends to complete a sale, joint venture or other options in the coming months.

headline: A Sticking Point in Glenn Beck’s Negotiations With CNN
abstract: Why did Glenn Beck decide to sign with the Fox News Channel? Bill Carter reports that “a sticking point in the talks with Mr. Beck to renew his contract was a plan by Headline News to drop the repeat of Mr. Beck’s show at 9 p.m.”

headline: Firdos Square’s Symbols: Then and Now
abstract: Firdos Square will always have symbolism. Because of one day: April 9, 2003.

headline: Government by Deal
abstract: The latest federal bailout will no doubt leave some straining to find consistency in the government’s efforts to stabilize the financial markets.

headline: Norwest Venture Partners Favor Single Global Fund
abstract: One venture firm argues that there are advantages to investing out of one global fund instead of several country-specific funds.

headline: When to Work for Nothing
abstract: Michelle Goodman, the author of a new book on managing a freelance career, writes a guest post on when it makes sense to work for free.

headline: Premier Foods May Receive Private Equity Injection, Report Says
abstract: Britain’s Premier Foods, home to brands such as Hovis bread and Branston pickle, is in talks with private equity shops about a possible cash injection to shore up its balance sheet, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Headline of the Day
abstract: “IMF needs some Facebook friends,” writes The Financial Times.

headline: Word Reaches Congress: As the Market Goes, So Goes the Electorate
abstract: What Representative Joe Barton, Republican of Texas, has heard from constituents this week about the Bush administration’s $700 billion economic bailout plan has fluctuated as wildly as the stock markets.

headline: Credit Crisis Is Bad News for Colleges
abstract: The Chronicle of Higher Education reports that Wachovia Bank has frozen the accounts of nearly 1,000 colleges.

headline: The Netherlands’ Aegon May Be Latest to Take Advantage of Federal Aid
abstract: Aegon may tap into a 20 billion euro ($25.17 billion) fund set up by the Netherlands in order to shore up its financial institutions, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Buyouts in a Debt-Starved World
abstract: The seized-up credit markets are forcing buyout firms large and small to rewrite their playbooks, and Investment Dealers’ Digest looks at how strategies have changed.

headline: Podcast: An Account of the Shoe-Throwing Incident
abstract: Atheer Kakan was in the press briefing when an Iraqi journalist threw his shoes at President Bush.

headline: Legal Contortions in the Battle Over Wachovia
abstract: Updated at 5:54 p.m.

headline: A Dreadful Jobs Report Recalls the 1980s
abstract: The labor market is headed toward a slump not seen in a quarter-century.

headline: Elections Are Fertile Ground for Testing Market Soothsayers
abstract: In 1967, after several years of research, a young market forecaster named Yale Hirsch unveiled a grand theory of the relationship between presidential elections and the stock market.

headline: The Methuselah of Software Packages?
abstract: “The Print Shop” program from Broderbund is up to version 23. Has any other software had so many incarnations?

headline: Glenview Capital Said to Lay Off A Dozen Staff, Reduce Pay
abstract: Larry Robbins’ Glenview Capital laid off about a dozen of its 85-member staff last week, The New York Post reported.

headline: Prosecutors Said to Probe Whether Lehman Misled Analysts
abstract: U.S. federal prosecutors probing the collapse of Lehman Brothers Holdings have subpoenaed other securities firms, asking whether their analysts were misled by Lehman about its financial health, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Major Changes at NBC Entertainment
abstract: NBC Universal is shaking up its entertainment division.

headline: Elevation Bets Another $100 Million on Palm
abstract: Palm, the maker of the Treo and other handheld gadgets, secured $100 million from its private equity backer, Elevation Partners, giving it more breathing room as it tries to steer a turnaround.

headline: Less Glass = Fewer TVs = Lower Prices?
abstract: Television manufacturers continue to promote a rosy sales picture for the flat-panel TV industry, but inside developments indicate something different.

headline: The Citi Restraining Order and Supporting Motion
abstract: DealBook has both Judge Charles Ramos’s temporary restraining order and Citigroup‘s memorandum supporting it. Read both after the jump.

headline: TARP’s Powers Give Pause to Private Equity
abstract: Last week, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. floated the idea of encouraging private capital to invest in financial institutions alongside the government’s Troubled Assets Relief Program — possibly through something he called “matching investments.”

headline: Fairfield Greenwich Is Sued Over Madoff Investment
abstract: The lawsuits in the Bernard L. Madoff matter are multiplying, as a pair of investors on Monday sued an investment manager that had invested in the massive Ponzi scheme.

headline: Yes, Newspaper Endorsements Matter…
abstract: A new study found that newspaper endorsements of candidates do influence voter preferences, but the amount of influence depends largely on whether the endorsement is believed to be motivated by political bias.

headline: Simpson’s $300,000 Treasury Fee
abstract: How much does it cost to hire a legal adviser for a $700 billion bailout plan?

headline: An Elephant Backs Up Google’s Library
abstract: A group of major libraries join to create a backup to Google’s book-scanning project.

headline: How Cheap Are Stocks?
abstract: Looking at the fundamentals to get a sense for where the market may be headed.

headline: Big Fund’s Clients Seek Taped Proof of Tip-Offs
abstract: Customers who are suing the Reserve Fund have asked a federal judge to allow the release of audio tapes of calls that the fund’s sales staff made to customers on Sept. 15, the day before the money market fund’s share price fell below a dollar, The New York Times’s Diana B. Henriques reported.

headline: When Citi Lost Sallie
abstract: On a Saturday in late September, at a corporate retreat at the Phoenician resort in Scottsdale, Ariz., Sallie L. Krawcheck gave a speech thanking her troops at Citigroup for their hard work, and then returned to her room.

headline: Hartford’s Shares Plunge After Reporting Big Loss
abstract: The Hartford Financial Services Group lost about half its stock market value on Thursday after the big property and life insurer posted a surprisingly large quarterly loss, raising concerns on Wall Street that it might need to raise more capital.

headline: Lawyers Sentenced for Role in Kickback Scheme
abstract: Two former law firm partners who helped prosecutors unravel a lucrative lawsuit kickback scheme that raked in nearly $240 million for their firm were each sentenced to six months in federal prison on Monday.

headline: Access Executive Said He Would ‘Fight’ for Madoff Funds
abstract: From Nelson D. Schwartz, a DealBook colleague in Paris:

headline: Kerkorian Sells Part of His Ford Stake
abstract: The Tracinda Corporation, the investment company controlled by the billionaire financier Kirk Kerkorian, said Tuesday in a regulatory filing that it had sold 7.3 million shares of the automaker, the Ford Motor Company, and might sell the rest of the stock.

headline: Wachtell Lipton’s Lessons from Lehman
abstract: The bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers stands apart from other financial failures, not only for its sheer size ($639 billion in assets) but also for the amount of misery it spread through the global financial system. Many of Lehman’s trading partners and clients were left holding the bag after the firm melted down, which has had disastrous knock-on effects.

headline: Google and Yahoo Revise Their Search Advertising Pact
abstract: Google and Yahoo have sent the Justice Department a revised search advertising deal aimed at appeasing antitrust regulators who have raised concerns about the original deal, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

headline: Credit Suisse Swaps Assets for Aberdeen Stake
abstract: Credit Suisse Group said it would sell parts of its asset-management business to Aberdeen Asset Management, a British firm, in exchange for a 24.9 percent stake in Aberdeen.

headline: Massa’s seven-point advantage
abstract: Yes, Lewis Hamilton is leading the drivers’ series by five points only on Felipe Massa with only two races left. But for the second time in four races, Massa has gained a points advantage thanks to questionable penalties applied to others by the race stewards. And each time, by the way, the penalty was applied in the same manner.

headline: Circuit City Receives Approval for $1.1 Billion DIP Loan
abstract: Circuit City Stores, the nation’s second-biggest electronics retailer, received final approval Monday for $1.1 billion in debtor-in-possession financing in order to keep operating while it’s in Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, The Associated Press reported.

headline: An ‘Obama Effect’ for TV Casting?
abstract: After years of dramas sprinkled with nonwhite supporting actors, the excitement surrounding Barack Obama could usher in more minorities in leading dramatic roles.

headline: Departing Chief Says NBC Has Become Fully Digital
abstract: With the departure of George Kliavkoff, NBC will no longer have a chief digital officer. He says the job is no longer needed.

headline: Ratings: Ten Million Watch ‘Boston Legal’ Finale
abstract: The two-hour series finale of “Boston Legal” attracted 10.2 million viewers on Monday as the dark comedy on ABC, concluding its fifth and final season, earned its largest audience of the fall.

headline: Hanukkah Economics
abstract: A collection of links on the economics of the Festival of Lights.

headline: Caller ID for Your Cell Is Nice, but at What Price?
abstract: A new Caller ID service from Verizon gives you the geographic location of the caller. But at $2 a month, is it worth it?

headline: Big Energy Companies Still Welcome in Credit  Markets
abstract: Raising cash in the debt markets these days has become nearly impossible for many companies, even for the bluest of blue chips. But there are certain companies that have had an easier time than others: large energy companies.

abstract: Japan announced a stimulus package on Thursday that includes $51 billion to help households and businesses, the boldest of several measures that officials took to try to stanch the global credit crisis, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener said.

abstract: The electric car start-up says investors have committed $40 million to help the company out of its financial trouble.

headline: MySpace and MTV Turn Pirated Video Into Ad Dollars
abstract: MySpace says it will begin selling ads against some television clips on its site, even if they are pirated.

abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

abstract: “I and others were mistaken early on in saying that the subprime crisis would be contained.”

headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai
abstract: FountainVest Partners, a China-focused private equity fund, was officially launched in Shanghai late last week.

headline: Lots of Losers in the ‘Madoff Game’
abstract: How in the world can someone make $50 billion disappear?

headline: After Congressional Flap, Word Comes of More A.I.G. Junkets
abstract: The American International Group has already been embarrassed once this week by revelations of a $440,000 junket at the St. Regis resort in California. Now, according, to The New York Post, the struggling insurance giant may be ripe for another round of ribbing.

headline: Laughter in Spring, Death in Autumn
abstract: It was one of those conversations that stayed with me — an interview last spring with a shoe store owner in the Karrada neighborhood for a story about April Fools day, which here is called Kithbet Nisan, or April Lie.

headline: Hulu, YouTube, iTunes Take a Walk on Sesame Street
abstract: After almost four decades on Public Broadcasting Service-affiliated television stations, the popular children’s program ‘Sesame Street’ is moving to the Internet.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Relief Rally
abstract: What a difference a deal makes.

headline: Senna vs. Prost
abstract: We all remember or know of the great Ayrton Senna versus Alain Prost battle of two decades ago. (Yes, it really goes back that far!) What fewer of us will know of is the unofficial, completely unpublicized dual career of the nephew and son of these two drivers, which as of yesterday has taken on considerable interest in my mind as a kind of parallel battle of the younger generation.

headline: Panasonic Gets Gold for the G1
abstract: Panansonic’s Lumix DMC-G1, the first Micro Four Thirds camera, wins a gold award.

headline: E.U. Clears KLM Takeover of Martinair
abstract: European Union regulators on Wednesday approved the takeover of Dutch charter and cargo airline Martinair by the Air France-KLM group.

headline: As Home Sales Slump, Realogy Juggles Its Debt
abstract: Hoping to lower its debt load in a housing market that is cratering, Realogy, the real-estate conglomerate controlled by Apollo Management, is offering its noteholders the chance to swap their debt for new loans — at a deep discount to the notes’ face value.

headline: It’s a Recession
abstract: The National Bureau of Economic Research said today that the current recession began a year ago, in December 2007.

headline: After Wall St. Tremors, Office Vacancy Rates Rise in Manhattan’s Shadow
abstract: The aftershock of the financial earthquake that hit Wall Street late in the summer is rattling two major suburban markets north of Manhattan. As elsewhere, office vacancy rates have been climbing in Westchester County, N.Y., and Fairfield County, Conn., which sit side by side, The New York Times’s Elsa Brenner writes.

headline: First Look at Windows 7
abstract: A sneak peek at Microsoft’s upcoming OS, Windows 7.

headline: Lawyer Is Accused in Huge Hedge Fund Fraud
abstract: His legal lineage was impeccable. A Yale man with a law degree from Harvard, he was a litigation powerhouse, a leader at some of the more prominent firms at the New York bar who then started a top-shelf practice of his own.

headline: Norinchukin Bank Takes Stake in Credit Agricole
abstract: Japan’s Norinchukin Bank said Friday it has acquired a 0.5 percent stake worth about about 30 billion yen, or $286 million, in France’s Credit Agricole, which has been shoring up its capital base after being hit by U.S. credit-related losses.

headline: Fraud Trial to Focus on Accounting at Heilig-Meyers
abstract: A securities fraud trial involving some of the biggest names on Wall Street begins Tuesday in New York, opening a window into the sale of asset-backed securities, The New York Times’s Lynnley Browning writes.

headline: American Express to Become Bank Holding Company
abstract: The Federal Reserve on Monday evening granted a request by American Express to become a bank holding company, giving it access to low-cost financing from the Fed.

headline: A Site for Workplace Scuttlebutt Gets More Financing
abstract: From Brad Stone at Bits:

headline: BlackRock, Pimco Said to Bid for Bailout Work
abstract: BlackRock and Pacific Investment Management Company are bidding to manage mortgage-backed assets in the U.S.’s $700 billion financial bailout, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: NBC’s Bronze-Medal Olympics DVD
abstract: NBC misses the whole HD boat with its Beijing Olympics DVD.

headline: More on Stock Valuation
abstract: With links to Buffett and Bogle.

headline: Las Vegas Sands to Detail Plans Next Week, Report Says
abstract: Casino giant Las Vegas Sands will detail its plans to handle its debt crisis early next week, according to a person close to the company, a development that may ease bankruptcy worries and could include another capital infusion by billionaire founder Sheldon Adelson, The Associated Press reported, citing a person close to the company.

headline: Hot Document: Robert Steel’s Affidavit
abstract: The increasingly messy fight over Wachovia spilled over into federal district court in lower Manhattan Sunday afternoon, as lawyers of various stripes assembled to argue over the Charlotte bank’s proposed $15.1 billion merger with Wells Fargo.

headline: Honoring Paul Krugman
abstract: Edward L. Glaeser writes in celebration of Paul Krugman.

headline: Bank Loans to Replace I.P.O.’s in China?
abstract: The newest source of funding in China is expected to be bank lending, primarily from local or large state-controlled banks as the government, desperate to prevent economic growth from slipping, is encouraging banks to make credit available to small and medium-sized businesses.

headline: ‘Fox News Channel Is Starting to Resemble the New York Yankees’
abstract: With the re-signing this week of Bill O’Reilly, the most successful host in cable news, to a four-year deal worth more than $10 million a year, the Fox News Channel is starting to resemble the New York Yankees.

headline: And the Banker of the Year Award Goes to …
abstract: Over the past year, JPMorgan Chase‘s James Dimon has garnered wide acclaim as a modern-day J. P. Morgan of sorts, swooping in to rescue ailing banks at the government’s behest.

headline: Dexia Sells U.S. Unit to Assured Guaranty
abstract: Belgian-French financial services group Dexia agreed to sell the insurance business of its loss-making Financial Security Guarantee to Assured Guaranty, the U.S. bond insurer backed by billionaire Wilbur Ross.

headline: Live Blog: The Automakers Plead
abstract: Updated at 3:45 p.m.

headline: Government Must Exit Private Enterprise In Time, Cox Says
abstract: The federal government must create strategies to eventually dilute its involvement with private enterprise, Securities Exchange Commission Chairman Christopher Cox wrote in an opinion piece published in The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Economists’ Reactions to Job Numbers
abstract: Economists in financial services and in academia respond to today’s employment report.

headline: Wachovia Shareholders Leap Into the Legal Fray
abstract: In a weekend flurry of attempted temporary restraining orders revolving around Wachovia, what’s one more?

headline: Measuring the Shock Waves in Bond Funds
abstract: Investors rarely brag about their individual bond holdings, but they are certainly complaining about them now, The New York Times’s Jeff Sommer writes.

headline: As Rivals Swoon, Credit Suisse Chief Is Confident
abstract: Most financial chieftans are sounding uncharacteristically humble these days, as they plead with investors for cash infusions or defend themselves in front of a firing squad of angry lawmakers. But Brady Dougan, the chief executive of Credit Suisse, is showing a little swagger.

headline: Seeing the (Bud) Light in a New Light
abstract: One of the most-marketed brands on television – Bud Light – is getting an advertising makeover that begins on Saturday, playing up the kinds of product benefits that were once played down in favor of funny animals and wacky human tricks.

headline: Optimism About Private Equity? One Study Says It’s Out There
abstract: Despite the problems plaguing the private equity industry these days, a chunk of institutional investors believe that their industry will continue to throw money into buyout funds.

headline: Hynix Semiconductor Works to Raise Cash
abstract: South Korea’s money-losing Hynix Semiconductor is making progress toward raising new capital from creditors and direct backing from the government is not being considered, officials said Monday.

headline: Officials Vow to Act Amid Forecasts of Long Recession
abstract: The United States economy officially sank into a recession last December, which means that the downturn is already longer than the average for all recessions since World War II, according to the committee of economists responsible for dating the nation’s business cycles.

headline: Commonwealth Bank Denies Bid for HBOS Unit
abstract: Commonwealth Bank of Australia poured cold water on report that it’s bidding for HBOS‘s Australian unit BankWest.

headline: Even a Hedge Fund Haven Feels Housing Pinch
abstract: Like cars in Detroit or chili in Texas, homes in Greenwich, Conn. play various roles, The New York Times’s Peter Applebome writes. Not just a dwelling, not just a way to keep score, houses – particularly the Versailles-like backcountry mansions in either their traditional or neo-monstrosity incarnations – are like an art form: critiqued, analyzed, psychoanalyzed, the way people in Manhattan used to obsess about, say, French New Wave cinema.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects ‘Survivor’ Winner’s Appeal
abstract: The U.S. Supreme Court has declined to hear Richard Hatch’s appeal of his conviction for failing to pay taxes on the $1 million prize he won on the debut season of ‘Survivor.’

headline: G.M. May Sell ACDelco Unit
abstract: General Motors has revealed another asset that might land on the auction block as the giant automaker seeks to raise as much as $4 billion from divestitures.

headline: Overreaction, or Coming Collapse?
abstract: With 60 percent of junk bonds trading as if default were likely, either some bonds are good buys or economic disaster is approaching.

headline: The Cubs Sale Delay: Timeout or Strikeout?
abstract: Sam Zell’s difficulty selling the Chicago Cubs doesn’t augur well for Major League Baseball. Since Mr. Zell bought the Tribune Company last year, he has been trying to sell a 95 percent stake in the Cubs, who haven’t won a World Series in a century.

headline: Uncertainty Surrounds G.M. and Chrysler Deal
abstract: The outlook for a deal between General Motors and Chrysler appeared unclear, as conflicting reports surfaced Monday.

abstract: “I’m happy that the V word isn’t so nasty anymore,” the longtime TV host Carol Burnett says.

abstract: Things are not looking up for hedge funds.

abstract: Lawyers are advising private equity and hedge funds to do a bit of restructuring before year’s end, in an effort to prepare themselves for the possibility that taxes on “carried interest” may more than double under the new presidential administration, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Firm Built on Madoff Ties Faces Tough Questions
abstract: Since Bernard L. Madoff was arrested 11 days ago in connection with a $50 billion Ponzi scheme, the Fairfield Greenwich Group has portrayed itself as an unwitting victim of the fraud, the biggest of Mr. Madoff’s many losers.

headline: Fears About Lehman Derivatives Deadline Seen as Overstated
abstract: Tuesday’s deadline to settle an estimated $400 billion in credit default swaps on debt in failed investment bank Lehman Brothers is unlikely to trigger new havoc in the market, derivatives analysts said.

headline: InBev Postpones $9.8 Billion Rights Offering
abstract: InBev‘s $52 billion deal to buy St. Louis-based Anheuser-Busch hit a snag this week, when the Belgian brewer announced that it was forced to postpone a $9.8 billion rights offering intended to help fund the purchase.

abstract: Daniel Alpert, managing director at Westwood Capital, an investment bank in New York, offers this view of the government’s bailout of General Motors and Chrysler:

abstract: Intel and A.M.D.’s long-running chip feud is carrying over to A.M.D.’s proposed factory spinoff.

headline: A Random Walk Off a Cliff: ‘Beating’ the Market
abstract: An economist asks, why don’t the experts have an advantage in stock picking? Or, do they? Are markets so efficient that they incorporate all relevant information instantly and leave us nothing to trade on? Or, can some investors “beat the market” consistently?

headline: Worries, Perhaps Too Many, About Collateralized Loans
abstract: The ghosts of the leverage buyout boom could come back to haunt banks across the globe, according to The Deal.com. There are increasing concerns that collateralized loan obligations – which provided money that fueled the surge in leveraged lending before the credit crisis – could soon cause serious problems for financial institutions that bought them thinking they were safe investments.

headline: G.E. Damps Down Earnings Expectations
abstract: General Electric said Tuesday that it expects its fourth-quarter profits to be at the low end of its previous guidance and warned that restructuring and other charges were likely to top $1 billion after taxes.

headline: Circuit City’s Bankruptcy
abstract: A year and a half after layoffs aimed at higher-paid workers, the electronics retailer seeks bankruptcy protection.

headline: A $2,000 Motorola Phone (Sapphire Crystal Display Included)
abstract: Stop paying so little for your mobile phone, you cheapskate! Motorola’s new Aura costs $2,000. It’s got ball bearings.

headline: Digitalsmiths Nabs $12 Million
abstract: Digitalsmiths, an online video indexing, analytics and publishing technology provider, has landed $12 million in a second round of funding, led led by .406 Ventures.

headline: Internet Companies Hammered by Economic Concerns
abstract: Internet stocks take a hit along with the rest of the market.

abstract: The nation’s largest pension fund, the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, named an investment strategist, Anne Stausboll, as its chief executive on Wednesday.

headline: Lawyer’s Arrest in Canada Leaves His Firm in Chaos
abstract: Marc Stuart Dreier, a high-living New York lawyer who has a gaggle of celebrity clients and a large firm that bears his name, was released from a Canadian jail on Friday after promising to return to court to face charges that he impersonated another lawyer on Tuesday at the offices of a large Canadian pension fund, The New York Times’s Alison Leigh Cowan and William K. Rashbaum reported.

headline: Wachovia Posts $23.9 Billion 3rd-Quarter Loss
abstract: Wachovia reported a $23.9 billion net loss for its third quarter, as the struggling bank took nearly $19 billion in goodwill impairment and $6.6 billion in charges related to potential losses on its troublesome mortgages.

headline: Tesla Promised Another $40 Million, Loses Lawsuit
abstract: The electric car start-up says investors have committed $40 million to help the company out of its financial trouble.

headline: MySpace and MTV Turn Pirated Video Into Ad Dollars
abstract: MySpace says it will begin selling ads against some television clips on its site, even if they are pirated.

headline: Credit Suisse Expands Its Business in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

headline: We Made Mistakes, Fed Chairman Says
abstract: “I and others were mistaken early on in saying that the subprime crisis would be contained.”

headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai
abstract: FountainVest Partners, a China-focused private equity fund, was officially launched in Shanghai late last week.

headline: Don’t Just Spend, Do It Wisely
abstract: An economist argues that the government should spend money on infrastructure projects in order to dig the economy out of recession, but lawmakers should apply the same cost-benefit analysis to the fiscal stimulus package that they would (or should) apply to any other federal spending.

headline: Forrester Chief on What Not to Cut in a Downturn
abstract: Broadband adoption, cellphone use and e-commerce have all surged since the last tech recession, so this downturn will be different, says George Colony of Forrester.

headline: Fed Approves Wells Fargo-Wachovia Deal
abstract: The Federal Reserve on Sunday gave its stamp of approval to the takeover of Wachovia by Wells Fargo, which had battled Citigroup for ownership of the wounded bank.

headline: G.M. Blocked from Restarting Employee Stock Plan
abstract: Amid its serious financial troubles, General Motors has run into yet another roadblock: It can’t restart its employee stock-purchase program, which was suspended in September.

headline: Deutsche Rejects a Rescue
abstract: Deutsche Bank fancies itself a shining exception to the prevailing view that giant banks need rescuing by governments. But, The New York Times’s Carter Dougherty writes, the financial markets will have the final word, and so far they are not buying the story, or Deutsche stock.

headline: Citadel’s Griffin Finds Himself on the Defense
abstract: Kenneth C. Griffin was one of those Wall Street whiz kids. As a teenager, he traded out of his dorm room at Harvard. In his 20s, he opened his own hedge fund. In his 30s, he boasted that his company might one day rival Goldman Sachs.

headline: Parsing Wells Fargo: Just When He Thought He Was Out…
abstract: At every Wells Fargo water cooler this week, middle managers were undoubtedly showing off their Michael Corleone impersonations after the company announced that its board had voted to waive its mandatory retirement age so that it could pull back in its accomplished chairman, Dick Kovacevich.

headline: Ratings: ‘The Mentalist’ Draws 14.9 Million
abstract: Crime dramas propelled CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday, although Fox led the night in the 18-to-49 demographic thanks to “House” and “Fringe.”

headline: Kozlowski, in Jail, Wonders if He’ll Have Company
abstract: The world seems to be falling apart, and L. Dennis Kozlowski, the disgraced former chief executive of Tyco International, has something to say about it. In an interview from prison that is being shown on the Fox Business Network, Mr. Kozlowski says the government’s current financial bailout plan is akin to socialism and his misdeeds at Tyco pale in comparison to what happened at the American International Group, Lehman Brothers and Bear Stearns.

headline: Settlement With Former A.I.G. Chief Said to Break Down
abstract: Efforts to settle a long-running fraud lawsuit against American International Group‘s former chief, Maurice “Hank” Greenberg, have broken down amid the insurer’s financial woes, a lawyer from the New York attorney general’s office said on Monday.

headline: AT&T and the Theory of Specific Performance
abstract: If you are a strategic buyer about to be found in breach of your acquisition agreement, which would you prefer: a remedy whereby you are required to pay monetary damages, or one where you are forced to complete the deal (the remedy of specific performance)?

headline: G.M., Chrysler Said to Mull Alternatives to a Merger
abstract: Deal talks may be continuing between Chrysler and General Motors, but both companies are reportedly mulling alternatives to a hook-up.

headline: David Bonderman and the Kiss That Binds
abstract: Hedge funds may accommodate short-term hookups, but the private equity world is more keen on commitment.

headline: Jerry Yang, Yahoo Chief, Plans to Step Down
abstract: Yahoo said Jerry Yang, its chief executive, would leave that role after the company finds a replacement.

headline: S.E.C. Image Suffers in a String of Setbacks
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission, a once-proud agency with an impressive history as Wall Street’s top cop, finds itself increasingly conducting autopsies of leading financial institutions after failing, in the first instance, to perform adequate biopsies, The New York Times’s Stephen Labaton writes.

headline: The Creditors of Lehman Can Do Little but Wait
abstract: Creditors of Lehman Brothers‘ international business, arriving at London’s gigantic O2 concert hall on Friday, had no illusions about getting their money back any time soon, The New York Times’s Julia Werdigier reported.

headline: Reader Feedback: The Jobs Report
abstract: Did a lot of people really drop out of the labor force last month?

headline: How the Credit Crisis Might Help American Manufacturers
abstract: It’s hard to believe that the banking crisis can be good for anyone, but the credit crunch is starting to help some American companies at the expense of their foreign competitors, an economist says.

headline: Enriched by Randomness
abstract: Despite all the economic doom and gloom, some people, like Nassim Nicholas Taleb, are actually making money.

headline: The Case of the Photo, the Lawyers and the Automakers
abstract: In their ongoing effort to discern the Detroit Three’s attitudes toward possible restructuring or bankruptcy filings, observers have now turned to scrutinizing photographs.

headline: More Cuts at G.M. and Chrysler Amid Merger Talks
abstract: General Motors and Chrysler announced plans for more cutbacks Thursday as they continued to shrink their operations ahead of a possible merger, The New York Times’s Nick Bunkley reports from Detroit.

headline: Video: Iraqi Journalist’s Family Asks for His Release
abstract: The family of the Iraqi journalist who threw shoes at President Bush held a rally outside the Green Zone on Friday asking for his immediate release.

headline: Housing Prices
abstract: An interactive chart looks at the home-price trends over time in 20 major cities.

headline: More Video on Your Phone … in 2010
abstract: The Open Screen Project aims to have everything you see on your desktop on your mobile in about two years.

headline: Eye-Popping Video from a DSLR Camera
abstract: Canon introduces a DSLR camera that shoots video, the EOS 5D Mark II.

headline: New Combo LCD/Blu-ray TVs From Sharp
abstract: Sharp will introduce two new LCD TVs next month that add a Blu-ray player into the chassis.

headline: Verizon Said to Have Trouble Scaring Up Cash for Alltel Deal
abstract: Is Verizon Wireless‘ $28.1 billion deal to acquire Alltel in trouble?

headline: Recession Fears Send Global Stocks Lower
abstract: Stocks fell Tuesday in Europe and Asia amid deeply bearish sentiment stoked by expectations of a protracted global recession, The New York Times’s David Jolly and Bettina Wassener reported.

headline: For ABC, a Good Night to Go Dancing
abstract: ABC led Monday night with “Dancing With the Stars,” and CBS was second. And while the CW finished fifth, it fared particularly well among women aged 18 to 34.

headline: A Camcorder Insurgent Goes HD
abstract: Pure Digital, the fastest growing company in Silicon Valley, introduces the new Flip Mino HD camcorder.

headline: Stocks Are Hurt by Latest Fear: Declining Prices
abstract: After gyrating wildly for weeks, the stock market lurched lower on Wednesday, falling to its lowest point in nearly six years, as concern spread that the economy might be facing a chronic and debilitating decline in prices, The New York Times’s Vikas Bajaj reported.

headline: Baugur Said to Face Hard Choice Over Saks
abstract: Will Jon Asgeir Johannesson stay or will he go?

headline: Group of Economists Rallies Around the Bailout
abstract: From Economix: Last week a group of economists sent a petition to Congress opposing the bailout proposal. This Tuesday another group of economists, apparently worried about further delays in the bill’s passage, sent a counter-petition.

headline: Stocks and Earnings: Racing to the Bottom
abstract: Stocks are falling fast, but so are estimates of corporate earnings.

headline: Hedge Fund Failures Set 3rd-Quarter Record
abstract: A record number of hedge funds closed their doors in the third quarter of the year, amid increased investor redemptions and chaos in the financial markets, according to Hedge Fund Research.

headline: Wall Street Said to Turn Cold Shoulder to Cuomo Party
abstract: Andrew M. Cuomo is turning 51 in two weeks. But Wall Street executives don’t seem eager to bring him presents, despite being invited to his party.

headline: Tending to the Out-of-Work Hedge Funder
abstract: Many businesses have hit a slow patch, but these are busy times for Michael Madigan. He’s the 27-year-old client services director at Chelsea Technologies, a small operation that specializes in providing information technology services to hedge funds and small investment funds around New York City.

headline: General Growth, Mall Owner, May Be Facing a Sale
abstract: It took only six weeks of negotiations for General Growth Properties, the nation’s second-largest shopping mall owner and operator, to agree to buy the Rouse Company in 2004 for $12.6 billion, a breathtaking price at the time.

headline: Debating the Merits of Mark-to-Market
abstract: Accounting rules don’t normally inspire fierce passions and flowery speeches. But one such rule has generated huge controversy during the recent financial meltdown: That’s FAS 157, the 2006 accounting rule that sets standards for when certain securities need to be “marked to market.”

headline: Beck Leaving CNN for Fox News
abstract: Glenn Beck, the conservative commentator on CNN, is moving to the Fox News Channel.

headline: Short Squeeze
abstract: It’s a new fashioned short squeeze. Porsche has found a way to make money from VW securities, even if it can’t make money selling VW cars.

headline: Fujitsu Buys Out Siemens Stake in Joint Venture
abstract: Industrial conglomerate Siemens will sell its 50 percent stake in Fujitsu Siemens Computers to partner Fujitsu for 450 million euros ($567 million), the companies said in a statement Tuesday.

headline: Weill in Talks to Launch Private Equity Fund, Report Says
abstract: Sanford Weill, whose dealmaking built Citigroup into the complex financial institution it is today, is reportedly in talks to launch a private equity fund that would invest struggling financial firms, such as the one he once headed.

headline: Las Vegas Sands Still Seeks Financing, Report Says
abstract: Las Vegas Sands Corporation is moving ahead with plans to raise $2 billion for a resort-casino project in Macau, but it may hold off on trying to raise an additional $3.3 billion it also hoped to rope in, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Las Vegas Sands Shares Sink on Worries It May Bust
abstract: Investors on Thursday appeared to be betting heavily against the financial health of Las Vegas Sands.

headline: Banks Need to Broaden View of Risk, Fed Official Says
abstract: Banks need to take a much broader view of investment risk as they dig their way out of the current financial crisis, and mortgage-backed securities need to become simpler and much more transparent, a senior U.S. Federal Reserve official said on Monday, Reuters reported.

headline: Hertz, Missing Forecasts, Will Suspend Earnings Estimates
abstract: Hertz Global Holdings, the car and equipment rental firm backed by a consortium of private equity firms, said on Wednesday that reduced demand means it won’t meet its latest forecast, and suspended estimating earnings until the economy improves.

headline: New Denon Blu-ray Player Raises the Ante (and Price)
abstract: New reference-standard Blu-ray player from Denon does not skimp on features–or price.

headline: Are Too Many Banks Too Big to Fail?
abstract: The financial crisis is forcing regulators to encourage the creation of bigger, more interconnected institutions. In the short term, this may serve a useful purpose by allowing healthier, well-capitalized banks like Wells Fargo, Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase to shore up weaker ones.

headline: It’s Obama on the iPhone
abstract: The Obama iPhone application gets supporters to pitch the candidate to their friends and neighbors.

headline: Financial Bailout Package Shifts Focus
abstract: The Treasury Department on Wednesday officially abandoned the original strategy behind its $700 billion effort to rescue the financial system, as administration officials acknowledged that banks and financial institutions were as unwilling as ever to lend to consumers.

headline: Citigroup Chief Faces the Troops
abstract: Updated: Citigroup is cutting 50,000 jobs in the near term, largely by selling businesses, meaning fewer actual layoffs. The firm also said that it is seeking to shore up its capital base and cut risky positions.

headline: NYSE Euronext 3rd-Quarter Profit Falls
abstract: NYSE Euronext, the trans-Atlantic stock exchange operator, said Friday that third-quarter profit fell by 33 percent due merger costs, severance payments and a decline in European derivatives trading.

headline: Now What?
abstract: With markets plunging around the world, will central banks cut rates quickly?

headline: Toll’s Plea: Subsidize House Prices
abstract: Toll Brothers, the luxury home builder, wants the government to subsidize house prices

headline: Markets Consider Domino Effects If G.M. Fails
abstract: Heightened prospects of a bankruptcy filing by General Motors or Chrysler rippled through the markets early Friday. Some credit analysts suggested that a G.M. filing would force Ford Motor Company into bankruptcy protection as well and bring down a host of major auto-parts suppliers.

headline: Late-Day Selling Surge Drives Shares Down
abstract: For a few moments, Wall Street seemed on track for its most encouraging two-day performance in a month.

headline: When Steve Fossett’s Effects Were Found, a TV Crew Was Nearby
abstract: The hiker who stumbled upon Steve Fossett’s pilot’s license sought out a television crew to document the finding.

headline: Many Private Equity Auctions Are Shelved
abstract: Nearly 1 billion pounds ($1.73 billion) worth of mid-market private equity sales in Britain have been shelved since the beginning of October, The Independent reported.

headline: Ratings: Another Win for ‘Dancing’
abstract: Drawing an average of 19.7 million viewers, ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” delivered Monday night’s largest television audience, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Japan Plans $51 Billion in Stimulus to Economy
abstract: Japan announced a stimulus package on Thursday that includes $51 billion to help households and businesses, the boldest of several measures that officials took to try to stanch the global credit crisis, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener said.

headline: Analyst Widens Predicted Loss for Citigroup
abstract: Veteran banking analyst Richard Bove widened his fourth-quarter loss estimate for Citigroup , saying the bank may take sizable write-downs in its capital-markets operations, similar to those seen in Goldman Sachs ‘s and Morgan Stanley‘s fourth-quarter results.

headline: Insider to Head Calpers
abstract: The nation’s largest pension fund, the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, named an investment strategist, Anne Stausboll, as its chief executive on Wednesday.

headline: Lawyer’s Arrest in Canada Leaves His Firm in Chaos
abstract: Marc Stuart Dreier, a high-living New York lawyer who has a gaggle of celebrity clients and a large firm that bears his name, was released from a Canadian jail on Friday after promising to return to court to face charges that he impersonated another lawyer on Tuesday at the offices of a large Canadian pension fund, The New York Times’s Alison Leigh Cowan and William K. Rashbaum reported.

headline: Wachovia Posts $23.9 Billion 3rd-Quarter Loss
abstract: Wachovia reported a $23.9 billion net loss for its third quarter, as the struggling bank took nearly $19 billion in goodwill impairment and $6.6 billion in charges related to potential losses on its troublesome mortgages.

headline: Tesla Promised Another $40 Million, Loses Lawsuit
abstract: The electric car start-up says investors have committed $40 million to help the company out of its financial trouble.

headline: MySpace and MTV Turn Pirated Video Into Ad Dollars
abstract: MySpace says it will begin selling ads against some television clips on its site, even if they are pirated.

headline: Credit Suisse Expands Its Business in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

headline: We Made Mistakes, Fed Chairman Says
abstract: “I and others were mistaken early on in saying that the subprime crisis would be contained.”

headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai
abstract: FountainVest Partners, a China-focused private equity fund, was officially launched in Shanghai late last week.

headline: Musings on a Post-Credit World
abstract: As the financial crisis mutes into an economic one, we may see a lot of cases where prices that seemed reasonable now seem totally ridiculous.

headline: JPMorgan Reported to Be Closing Trading Group
abstract: JPMorgan Chase plans to eliminate its proprietary trading group, which trades the bank’s own money in stocks, bonds and commodities, and is likely lay off some traders in an effort to cut costs, several news organizations report.

headline: Cheaper Year-End Gifts at Google
abstract: In a cost-cutting move, Google gives Dream phones instead of cash as year-end gift to employees.

headline: Summers and Geithner: A Reading List
abstract: Studying up on the leading candidates to be the next Treasury secretary.

headline: Irregularity Uncovered at IndyMac
abstract: Two months before IndyMac Bancorp collapsed in July, at a cost of $8.9 billion to taxpayers, a top federal banking regulator allowed the bank to backdate a capital infusion and gloss over its deepening problems, The New York Times’ Edmund L. Andrews reported, citing the Treasury Department’s independent investigator.

headline: Treasury Sets Timetable to Pick Managers
abstract: The Treasury Department put its $700 billion bailout on a fast track on Monday, asking companies to submit bids for running the system by Wednesday and announcing its plan to select winners on Friday, The New York Times’s Edmund L. Andrews writes.

headline: Investors Said to Agitate for New Bofa-Merrill Deal
abstract: One of the most curious matters in the world of mergers and acquisitions right now is the widening chasm that is the deal spread of the Bank of America–Merrill Lynch combination.

headline: Qantas Chief Says BA Merger Faces Major Hurdles
abstract: Qantas Airways warned investors its proposed $5.6 billion merger with British Airways faced major obstacles over the terms of the deal and stressed there was a reasonable chance talks would fail.

headline: A Widget a Day….
abstract: A highly subjective look survey of the best widgets for the Macintosh.

headline: Steve & Barry’s Names Official for Turnaround
abstract: Harold Kahn, a longtime retail executive who has been at the helm of chains like Macy’s East, became chief executive of Steve & Barry’s on Thursday, The New York Times’s Stephanie Rosenbloom reported.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland to Axe 3,000, Report Says
abstract: Royal Bank of Scotland is poised to cut 3,000 jobs worldwide in the next few weeks after the banking sector was rocked by the global financial crisis, the BBC reported.

headline: Citigroup to Cut 50,000 Jobs
abstract: Citigroup said Monday that it would eliminate more than 50,000 jobs, in addition to cuts it had already announced, as the global banking giant hunkers down to weather the harshest financial environment in decades.

headline: Which Part of the Economy Will Carry Us Through This Recession?
abstract: Right now we’re in a recession, and it’s getting worse. What part of our economy will carry us through to recovery?

headline: Bill for Financial Bailout Seen as High as $7.4 Trillion
abstract: How much money is the United States willing to lend and spend to bail out the American financial system? The number crunchers at Bloomberg News estimated that the bill could possibly reach more than $7.4 trillion, or roughly half of the nation’s annual gross domestic product.

headline: One Billion Mice, and Counting
abstract: The computer mouse is 40 years old, but touchscreens may lead to its demise.

headline: All I Want for Tweetmas
abstract: Tweetmas lets Twitter users share their Christmas wish lists with their friends and the world.

headline: What Recession? Accel Partners Raises $1 Billion
abstract: For the first time, Accel Partners has moved into late-stage investing.

headline: Spitzer Said to Be Victim of Madoff Scam
abstract: Eliot Spitzer, who as New York attorney general was known as the “Sheriff of Wall Street” for his crusade against investment fraud, has acknowledged that his family was swindled by the man accused of running what could be the largest Ponzi scheme in history.

headline: Vice and Recession, Part II
abstract: Bonnie Fuller writes on the Times blog “The Moment” that sexual activity increases during an economic downturn.

headline: A Simple Fix
abstract: Here’s an idea: Tear down enough houses to create a housing shortage.

headline: 2 More Bidders Emerge for Neuberger Berman
abstract: The private equity firms Bain Capital Partners and Hellman & Friedman are facing competition after all in their bid for Lehman Brothers’ investment management business.

headline: FIA World Council decisions
abstract: This just in from today’s World Council decisions. Check out the FIA site for further additions:

headline: Hollywood Financier Is Arrested Again
abstract: Ryan Kavanaugh, one of Hollywood’s most prominent film financiers, was arrested for drunk driving, speeding and driving with a suspended license in October while still on probation for an earlier conviction for driving under the influence of alcohol, The New York Times’s Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes report.

headline: Fed Extends Some Credit Programs Through April 30
abstract: The Federal Reserve has extended the life of key programs aimed at busting through credit clogs and restoring stability to financial markets.

headline: It’s the Laptop, by a Nose
abstract: New figures show laptop computers are now the form factor of choice.

headline: Vote (or Don’t) Because You’re Better Than Everyone Else
abstract: An economist argues that people vote, or choose not to, not because they think they will or won’t be able to make a difference, but to feel superior.

headline: CB Richard Ellis to Raise $180 Million in Share Sale
abstract: CB Richard Ellis Group, the world’s largest real estate services firm, said on Wednesday that it expected to realize about $180 million from a public offering of 50 million shares priced at $3.77 per share.

headline: Growing Dismay Over Shrinking Bank Bonuses
abstract: From Julia Werdigier, a DealBook colleague in London:

headline: Mr. Tweet Recommends Friends to Follow
abstract: A way to find tweets worth reading on Twitter: Mr. Tweet.

headline: ABC Schedules a ‘Homeland Security’ Series
abstract: “Homeland Security USA,” a reality show produced with the full cooperation of several Department of Homeland Security agencies, will have its premiere Jan. 6 on ABC.

headline: Wells Fargo’s 3rd-Quarter Profit Drops 25%
abstract: Wells Fargo, whose planned purchase of Wachovia will create the largest U.S. retail branch banking network, said on Wednesday third-quarter profit fell 25 percent, hurt by higher credit losses and investment write-downs.

headline: A.I.G. Chief Says Asset Sales May Be Delayed
abstract: The chief executive of U.S. insurer American International Group, which is looking to shed assets around the globe as part of a $152 billion U.S. government rescue package, said that difficult markets may delay the sale plans, though certain units have attracted heavy interest.

headline: Hilco Said to Raise Bid for Woolworths Unit
abstract: Distressed investor Hilco has sweetened the terms of its one pound offer for Woolworths‘ retail division, The Times of London reported.

headline: Zillow Does Have Limits
abstract: The real-estate site Zillow lays off 25 percent of its staff as it prepares for an economic downturn.

headline: Crisis Counseling From Valley Veterans
abstract: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: Natixis’s Investment Banking Arm Took a Hit in Oct.
abstract: French bank Natixis said Wednesday its investment banking arm had a revenue loss of 250 million euros ($320 million) in October due to ”extremely difficult” market conditions.

headline: Paulson Said to Tap Goldman Alum for Bailout Fund
abstract: Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson is expected to name a fellow Goldman Sachs alumnus, Neel Kashkari, to oversee the $700 billion program to buy distressed assets from financial institutions, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Ackman Tells Target: Happy Holidays, See You in 2009
abstract: William A. Ackman is backing off from his plan to separate the retailer Target from its land — at least until after the holidays.

headline: Mitsubishi UFJ First-Half Profit Falls 64%
abstract: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Japan’s largest bank, said first-half net profit plunged 64 percent, hit by higher credit costs and losses on its shareholdings, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Vicious Circle
abstract: There is a vicious circle at work, in which falling profits produce job cuts which reduce incomes and lead to loan defaults, and on and on.

headline: Online Community Said to Raise $5 million
abstract: Online entertainment community Chakpak has attracted additional investment from venture capital companies Accel Partners and Canaan Partners, The Economic Times reported.

headline: Taxpayers at the Gate
abstract: In October, the British government suggested it would be as single-minded as Henry R. Kravis in seeking a decent financial return from the tens of billions of pounds it had committed to invest in domestic banks – now including £15 billion ($23 billion) for a 58 percent stake in the Royal Bank of Scotland.

headline: Merrill Lynch Sets Date for Merger Vote
abstract: “Your vote is very important.”

headline: K.K.R. to Take Stake in Chinese Dairy Business
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts plans to invest $100 million in a Chinese dairy-farm business, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Pilgrim’s Pride Plummets on Warning of Bankruptcy
abstract: Shares of Pilgrim’s Pride fell below $1 on Thursday, a day after a research report said there was a high probability that the chicken producer would file for bankruptcy protection in December.

headline: Law Firms Feel Strain of Layoffs and Cutbacks
abstract: You know things are bad when even lawyers are getting laid off.

headline: No Plans to Retire, Even at 100
abstract: Mildred Heath, a 100-year-old journalist and publisher from Nebraska, wins an “America’s Oldest Worker” award and discusses her career in a YouTube video.

headline: The Corporate Profits Boom vs. Recent Earnings Reports
abstract: A look at the corporate earnings drops coming in: Is this just a short-term cyclical decline, or is it something more lasting and more serious?

headline: Program Seeks to Preserve Iraqi History
abstract: U.S. and Iraqi officials launched a two-year, $14 million initiative on Monday to help preserve Iraq’s cultural heritage.

headline: Microsoft Chief Pours Cold Water on Yahoo Speculation
abstract: Software giant Microsoft dismissed speculation it might still be interested in a takeover of Internet firm Yahoo.

headline: Improve the F1 show?
abstract: Sometimes I wonder about how Formula One intends to “improve the show.” Maybe today’s practice session was not THE most exciting. But it was interesting. And for me the most interesting point is not that Timo Glock got the fastest time in the Toyota, as it’s their home track and who knows what they were doing. But the interesting point is that although we tend to look at the times in the usual way, with the stronger cars at the top – hey, again, Fernando Alonso second fastest as he continues his regain in form since Singapore – and the weaker ones at the bottom (well, all right, not Nick Heidfeld). But read through the lines: There was only one second separating the first car and the 18th car. I haven’t had a chance to check it, but Force India called it the tightest practice session all year.

headline: Emanuel Urges Aid for Auto Industry
abstract: In his first televised interviews since being named the chief of staff for President-elect Barack Obama, Rahm Emanuel on Sunday called for swifter action to lift the struggling auto industry and suggested Mr. Obama and President Bush might clash over a stimulus package, The New York Times’s Anahad O’Connor reported.

headline: Sue Decker’s Memo to the Yahoo Troops
abstract: Sue Decker tells Yahoos that the Google deal was just one of many pieces in Yahoo’s turnaround plan.

headline: GM to Sell Stake in Suzuki to Raise Cash
abstract: General Motors will sell its entire stake in Suzuki Motor for 22.37 billion yen ($230 million) to raise cash, the Japanese company said Monday, the Associated Press reported.

headline: Can ‘Law & Order’ Outlive ‘Gunsmoke’?
abstract: The classic Western ran from 1955-1975 on CBS; next Wednesday’s season premiere will herald 19 years for “Law & Order.”

headline: StarVest Partners: It’s All About Data
abstract: StarVest Partners’ latest investment in a data-driven company is Iron Solutions.

headline: Credit Crisis Is Bad News for M.B.A. Students
abstract: MBA students at the MIT Sloan School of Management are now scrambling to find alternative student loans after Citibank decided cancel the CitiAssist custom student loan program with the school.

headline: Apple Shares Rally as Analyst Touts Buyback
abstract: Shares of Apple rallied Wednesday after an analyst said the maker of iPhones and Mac computers is in excellent position to launch a “substantial” share buyback program.

headline: Icahn Said to Seek a Buyer for His Yacht
abstract: When hard times hit, yachts are apparently among the first things to go.

headline: Regional Banks Suffer From Tough 3rd Quarter
abstract: Three large regional banks all reported losses on Tuesday, and one, National City, announced that it would lay off about 14 percent of its work force. A fourth regional bank, U.S. Bancorp, said that its quarterly profit fell a larger-than-expected 47 percent.

headline: Japan Plans $51 Billion in Stimulus to Economy
abstract: Japan announced a stimulus package on Thursday that includes $51 billion to help households and businesses, the boldest of several measures that officials took to try to stanch the global credit crisis, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener said.

abstract: Veteran banking analyst Richard Bove widened his fourth-quarter loss estimate for Citigroup , saying the bank may take sizable write-downs in its capital-markets operations, similar to those seen in Goldman Sachs ‘s and Morgan Stanley‘s fourth-quarter results.

Rashbaum reported.
