abstract: The electric car start-up says investors have committed $40 million to help the company out of its financial trouble.

headline: MySpace and MTV Turn Pirated Video Into Ad Dollars
abstract: MySpace says it will begin selling ads against some television clips on its site, even if they are pirated.

headline: Credit Suisse Expands Its Business in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

headline: We Made Mistakes, Fed Chairman Says
abstract: “I and others were mistaken early on in saying that the subprime crisis would be contained.”

headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai
abstract: FountainVest Partners, a China-focused private equity fund, was officially launched in Shanghai late last week.

headline: Obama Asks Bush to Provide Help for Automakers
abstract: The struggling auto industry was thrust into the middle of a political standoff between the White House and Democrats on Monday as President-elect Barack Obama urged President Bush in a meeting at the White House to support immediate emergency aid, The New York Times’s Jackie Clames reported.

headline: Sezmi, a TV 2.0 Start-Up, Cuts 20 Percent of Staff
abstract: From Brad Stone at Bits:

headline: Saving Citi May Create More Fear
abstract: One bailout was not enough for Citigroup. And it may not be enough for other big banks, The New York Times’s Eric Dash writes.

headline: The Best (Free) Photoshop Tutorials of ’08
abstract: Photoshop Lady releases its favorite Photoshop tutorials for 2008, including how to enhance lighting or make someone look older.

headline: Digital TV Switch Will Be Messy, F.C.C. Official Says
abstract: A pending mandatory switch of all U.S. televisions to digital will be messy, a federal communications official said on Tuesday, urging broadcasters to step up local efforts to educate the public.

headline: Tumblr Takes $4.5 Million
abstract: Tumblr, a service that lets users publish short, simple blog posts, has raised $4.5 million in a second round of funding.

headline: Leno Puts a Dent in the ‘Checkerboard’
abstract: The announcement of Jay Leno’s 10 p.m. show continues to reverberate on studio lots and executive corridors in Hollywood, as the Monday-through-Friday “strip” is unprecedented in the modern network television era.

headline: Universal Studios Discusses Sale of a Film Unit
abstract: Universal Studios is in advanced talks to sell one of its two specialty film labels to Relativity Media, a private production and financing company, The New York Times’s Brooks Barnes reported.

headline: A Netbook for the Desktop
abstract: Asus’s Eee Box B203 is simple, small and cheap.

headline: Detroit’s Bid for Aid Fails – For Now
abstract: The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi of California, and the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said at a joint news conference that any legislative proposal put to a vote this week would have failed, and they leveled scathing criticism at the executives that included pointed barbs for flying to Washington this week on private jets.

headline: A Snarl of Regulation
abstract: Who’s to blame for the implosion of financial markets? The finger-pointing has gone in every direction, and, The New York Times’s Hannah Fairfield writes, it’s easy to see why: the regulatory structure points in every direction.

headline: Deutsche Bahn I.P.O. May Be Delayed
abstract: The German government’s plan to float Deutsche Bahn‘s train division could be delayed because of the turmoil in the global credit markets, The Financial Times Deutschland reported.

headline: Road Ahead Is Long for G.M.
abstract: Will bankruptcy work for the Big Three?

headline: Young Start-Ups Drew Lots of Cash
abstract: Despite the turmoil in the markets and the economy, venture capitalists invested more than $7 billion in seed and early-stage companies in more than 1,400 deals in the past four quarters, according to the MoneyTree Report from the National Venture Capital Association. BusinessWeek reported that the figure represents more money raised by young companies than in any calendar year since the dot-com bubble burst in 2001.

headline: Election: Struggling to Cover ‘A Moment That Defied Description’
abstract: “Usually, anchors are unctuously expert at hyperbole and indirection. But on a night that actually was historic, when reality did outdo even the most elaborate effusions, simplicity worked best.”

headline: Daimler Writes Chrysler Stake Down to Zero
abstract: Daimler may still own 19.9 percent of Chrysler, but the book value of its investment in the troubled automaker just vanished.

headline: British Leader Calls for Larger I.M.F. Bailout Fund
abstract: Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain called Tuesday for China and the Persian Gulf states to put up more money to help the International Monetary Fund deal with the fallout of the credit crisis.

headline: No Bonuses for 7 Senior Executives at Goldman
abstract: As public scrutiny of Wall Street pay intensifies, one bank has already decided what it will award in bonuses to its top seven executives this year: nothing.

headline: After Financial Crisis, Uncertainty and Lectures From Abroad
abstract: As America’s financial crisis was gathering speed, Brazil’s president seemed dismissive, almost gleeful, about the troubles up north.

headline: Hyper-Local News Service Outside.In Grows
abstract: Outside.In wants to resuscitate local news by using geotagging to simulate a reporter on every corner.

headline: Why the Bailout Won’t Have to Compete With Medicare or Universal Coverage
abstract: In their first debate, the presidential candidates were ask whether, given the financial crisis, they would have to modify their campaign promises. An economist says the answer is no.

headline: Recession as a Marketing Strategy
abstract: Has it become newsworthy when a company is still doing well?

headline: Come With Me to the F.O.M.C.: A Sneak Peek Into Fed Life
abstract: An economist writes about what it was like to be a member of the Federal Open Market Committee and set monetary policy.

headline: UBS Hires Tech Banker from Lehman
abstract: It’s not all gloom and doom for UBS bankers.

headline: Bailout Monitor Sees Lack of a Coherent Plan
abstract: The head of a new Congressional panel set up to monitor the gigantic federal bailout says the government still does not seem to have a coherent strategy for easing the financial crisis, despite the billions it has already spent in that effort, The New York Times’s Diana B. Henriques reported.

headline: The Election and M&A
abstract: How could the election outcome affect the environment for mergers and acquisitions? A managing director from Harris Williams & Company, a middle-market investment bank, offered his thoughts to the Dealscape blog.

headline: Happy Holidays From Citi’s I-Banking Chief
abstract: Citigroup bankers may not have a lot to be thankful for this year (except perhaps their jobs). But the banking giant’s management is still extending its thanks to the firm’s employees.

headline: The S.E.C.’s Complaint Against Madoff
abstract: On Thursday, the Securities and Exchange Commission filed a lawsuit against Bernard L. Madoff, the legendary trader, accusing him of perpetrating one of the largest Ponzi schemes ever devised.

headline: Fund Investors Sue Countrywide Over Loan Modifications
abstract: As policy makers push banks to help struggling homeowners, some angry investors are pushing back.

headline: What a Chastened Goldman Might Look Like
abstract: Goldman Sachs transformed itself in 1999, when it went from a private partnership to a public company. Now it must transform itself again — but under far less happy circumstances.

headline: Digital Screen Deal Is Announced
abstract: Five Hollywood studios have agreed to help pay for a $1 billion-plus rollout of digital technology on about 20,000 movie screens in North America, a precursor to showing movies in 3-D.

headline: Former Merrill Executive Faces New Troubles at Bernstein
abstract: A twenty-two year veteran of Goldman Sachs — and the recent recipient of a $25 million golden parachute from Merrill Lynch — who this week took over this week as head of AllianceBernstein, will face a rockier future in his new job, The New York Post reported.

headline: Which Generation Has It Worst?
abstract: Voice your opinion on which generation will suffer most as a result of today’s financial crisis.

headline: Citysearch Learns to Coexist With Search Engines
abstract: With a new design, Citysearch is weaving its business reviews and advertising into search engines and social networks.

headline: A Splashy Product Integration, Canceled Along With the Show
abstract: General Motors’ splashy deal to integrate two vehicles into the NBC drama “My Own Worst Enemy” hit a snag Thursday when the network confirmed that it was canceling the series after only four episodes had been shown.

headline: Links to Krugman’s Research
abstract: Citations and links to the research that won Paul Krugman his Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science.

headline: Reforming Unemployment Benefits
abstract: Lawmakers are talking about further extending unemployment benefits. An economist writes about other potential reforms to the program.

headline: Circuit City’s Woes May Hurt Electronics Makers
abstract: Consumer electronics companies like retailers that compete against one another — and that they can play against one another.

headline: Blunt Advice for Treasury on Progress of the Bailout
abstract: Congressional lawmakers gave the Treasury Department two pieces of advice on Wednesday about the nation’s financial rescue plan: First, follow the money. Second, fight more aggressively against the rising tide of home foreclosures.

headline: Wall Street’s Pay Is Expected to Plummet
abstract: The first clues are emerging that Wall Street pay will plummet this year – but perhaps not enough to satisfy the financial industry’s critics, The New York Times’s Ben White writes.

headline: Despite Turmoil, Bankers Get Their Phone Deal
abstract: CenturyTel‘s deal to buy Embarq, valued at about $11.6 billion including debt, is one of the few big-ticket deals to be struck during the recent financial typhoon.

headline: New York May Lose 225,000 Jobs in Market Slump
abstract: New York may want to throw out the budget-cutting scissors and grab a machete.

headline: Discover, Visa And MasterCard Settle Antitrust Suit
abstract: Discover Financial Services has agreed to settle an antitrust lawsuit it filed in 2004 against card networks Visa and MasterCard. Discover had been seeking about $6 billion in damages, as it contended the card networks had harmed its business by preventing their member banks from issuing credit cards for Discover’s network.

headline: Carlyle Eyes Bank Investments
abstract: The Carlyle Group‘s co-founder, David Rubenstein, said on Wednesday that private equity had a great opportunity to invest in banks and other financial companies hit hard by the global credit crunch.

headline: Recruiting Firm Is Sued Over Citadel Hire
abstract: JPMorgan Chase Bank on Thursday accused a New York recruitment agency in a lawsuit of helping Citadel Investment Group entice executives to leave the financial institution.

headline: Politicos Scramble for New Jobs, Like So Many Other Americans
abstract: As President-elect Obama chooses his transition team, one thing is for certain: thousands of politicos in both parties are looking for new jobs. This morning I was a guest on WNYC Radio’s “The Takeaway” with John Hockenberry and Adaora Udoji to talk about how political types find new jobs when an administration changes, and what the rest of us can learn from their experiences. (You can listen to the show here, and I’ll recap below, including some points I planned to make but didn’t get to in the conversation.)

headline: And Here’s Me With…
abstract: In Iraq’s western Anbar Province, President-elect Barack Obama already figures prominently in framed pictures on the walls of mudhifs, or tribal guest rooms, and is now frequently evoked in the discourse of the sheiks, or tribal leaders.

headline: MSNBC’s Ad Echoes Obama’s Message
abstract: Watch MSNBC, a new commercial for the cable channel intones, and “experience the power of change.”

headline: For a New Show on Spike, ’60 Minutes’ Is 58 Too Many
abstract: Live shows were once a staple of television. Ditto game shows and shows with sponsor products interwoven into the contents. Now the Spike TV cable channel is bringing all three genres back in one fell swoop.

headline: Goldman Fund Said to Lose $1 Billion Since January
abstract: One of Goldman Sachs‘s flagship hedge funds has lost close to $1 billion since its start in January, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Banks Brace for Slump as Economy Weakens
abstract: JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo, and State Street have weathered these bad times better than most banks. But things are about to get worse, The New York Times’s Eric Dash writes.

headline: Overseas, More Nations Assemble Stimulus Plans
abstract: Australia was widely expected to cut interest rates on Tuesday and South Korea announced a $10.9 billion stimulus package on Monday, the latest in a string of steps by governments seeking to prop up growth and cushion the impact of the financial crisis, The New York Times’s Victoria Burnett and Bettina Wassener reported.

headline: Broadway Keep Tabs on Wall Street Drama
abstract: For people who work in and around Broadway, as for pretty much everyone else in the country, the main stage in recent weeks has been on Wall Street. Those in both the for-profit theater industry, which depends on wealthy investors, and the nonprofit world, which depends on corporate donations, are anxiously watching to see just what kind of fallout will land on them, The New York Times’s Patricia Cohen writes.

headline: SocGen Remains Profitable for 3rd Quarter
abstract: Societe Generale said it remained profitable in the third quarter at the net level, even when including charges related to the collapse of investment bank Lehman Brothers.

headline: Net Start-Ups Slow Their Metabolism
abstract: Silicon Valley has always been a land of big, bold dreams. In the first Internet boom its start-ups either grew fast or died trying, sometimes spectacularly. The casualties of the bust, like Pets.com and Webvan, became legendary. In this downturn, say investors and entrepreneurs, start-ups are adopting a strategy that they hope will let them hang on instead of flame out, The New York Times’ Brad Stone and Claire Cain Miller write.

headline: Highbridge Cuts 10% of Employees
abstract: Highbridge Capital, the hedge fund that is majority-owned by JPMorgan Chase, has laid off 10 percent of its workforce, or 35 employees, a person briefed on the matter said, as the environment for hedge funds remains harsh.

headline: Hot iPhone App: Google Voice Search
abstract: Google’s free voice search application for the iPhone is now available. It works.

headline: The Credit Crunch Continues
abstract: Credit market dispatches from today:

headline: A Slice of Glasnost at Apple
abstract: Apple announced that it would no longer enforce its nondisclosure agreement for software it has released.

headline: Did Deregulation Cause the Credit Crisis?
abstract: In Tuesday night’s debate, Senator Barack Obama largely blamed deregulation for the current economic crisis. But is that indeed the case?

headline: Japan Plans $51 Billion in Stimulus to Economy
abstract: Japan announced a stimulus package on Thursday that includes $51 billion to help households and businesses, the boldest of several measures that officials took to try to stanch the global credit crisis, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener said.

headline: Analyst Widens Predicted Loss for Citigroup
abstract: Veteran banking analyst Richard Bove widened his fourth-quarter loss estimate for Citigroup , saying the bank may take sizable write-downs in its capital-markets operations, similar to those seen in Goldman Sachs ‘s and Morgan Stanley‘s fourth-quarter results.

headline: Insider to Head Calpers
abstract: The nation’s largest pension fund, the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, named an investment strategist, Anne Stausboll, as its chief executive on Wednesday.

headline: Lawyer’s Arrest in Canada Leaves His Firm in Chaos
abstract: Marc Stuart Dreier, a high-living New York lawyer who has a gaggle of celebrity clients and a large firm that bears his name, was released from a Canadian jail on Friday after promising to return to court to face charges that he impersonated another lawyer on Tuesday at the offices of a large Canadian pension fund, The New York Times’s Alison Leigh Cowan and William K. Rashbaum reported.

headline: Wachovia Posts $23.9 Billion 3rd-Quarter Loss
abstract: Wachovia reported a $23.9 billion net loss for its third quarter, as the struggling bank took nearly $19 billion in goodwill impairment and $6.6 billion in charges related to potential losses on its troublesome mortgages.

headline: Tesla Promised Another $40 Million, Loses Lawsuit
abstract: The electric car start-up says investors have committed $40 million to help the company out of its financial trouble.

headline: MySpace and MTV Turn Pirated Video Into Ad Dollars
abstract: MySpace says it will begin selling ads against some television clips on its site, even if they are pirated.

headline: Credit Suisse Expands Its Business in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

headline: We Made Mistakes, Fed Chairman Says
abstract: “I and others were mistaken early on in saying that the subprime crisis would be contained.”

headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai
abstract: FountainVest Partners, a China-focused private equity fund, was officially launched in Shanghai late last week.

headline: Saturday-Night Special at Landry’s
abstract: This is a sad story.

headline: First Bankruptcy, and Then a Possible Bailout
abstract: There is a middle path between bailout billions and car company catastrophe, an economist writes: the possibility of limited government aid after a bankruptcy filing.

headline: Icahn Takes Stake in Another Drug Maker
abstract: Carl C. Icahn can’t seem to get enough of drug companies.

headline: Webify Lets You Easily Tweak Web Images
abstract: A new version of Webify expands the capabilities of the photo-editing software and costs less than $10.

headline: Britain Plans Bank Bailout Worth Hundreds of Billions
abstract: As European leaders continued to clash over measures to ease the financial crisis, Britain announced a three-part multibillion-dollar bailout for its beleaguered banks, and Spain moved to mount a separate rescue of its own banking sector, The New York Times’s Landon Thomas Jr. and Carter Dougherty reported.

headline: Estonia’s Let-It-Be Economy Is Rattled by Worldwide Distress
abstract: For nearly two decades, Estonia embraced capitalism with such gusto that it seemed to be channeling the laissez-faire philosophy of Milton Friedman. From its policies meant to attract foreign investors to its flat tax and freewheeling business culture, it stood out as the former Soviet republic most adept at turning post-Communist chaos into a thriving market economy.

headline: Trailing Its Rivals, Dell Looks to Deals
abstract: As Dell finds itself playing catch-up in one of the most difficult economic times in its history, what was once the world’s largest PC vendor is planning plans a run of acquisitions to restore growth, The New York Times’s Ashlee Vance writes. Its strategy hinges just as much on big bets as precise execution.

headline: Local News Service Outside.In Grows
abstract: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: Frank Sees ‘Disaster’ if Auto Industry Fails
abstract: “I hope we will do something.”

headline: Getting in the Holiday Shopping Spirit
abstract: A comic from xkcd.com.

headline: CIT Is Approved to Convert Into Bank
abstract: The CIT Group, a commercial lender, won federal approval to convert to a bank holding company, a step toward getting an investment of as much as $2.5 billion from the federal government.

headline: Qantas And B.A. Merger Talks Grounded
abstract: A deal between Australia’s Qantas Airways and British Airways just won’t fly.

headline: Banks Want Clarity Soon on Fair Value Accounting
abstract: Banks on Tuesday pleaded with regulators to immediately clarify fair value accounting rules and said failure to do so would negate the government’s efforts to shore up the financial sector.

headline: Three Start-Ups, a Year Later
abstract: This has been a gut-wrenching first year in business for three entrepreneurs whose start-ups were profiled in Brent Bowers’ column in The New York Times last December.

headline: Talkin’ Tech Tips
abstract: Tech videos for the hard- and not-so-hard-core user.

headline: Live-Blogging the Citadel Conference Call
abstract: Summary: Nothing was discussed on the Citadel call that differed materially from what The New York Times’s Louise Story and others have reported about the fund, other than that the firm’s flagship Kensington and Wellington funds are now down about 35 percent year to date. But it seems big to us that Citadel had to host a conference call at all.

headline: Fidelity’s Magellan Fund Buys Big Banks In September
abstract: Fidelity Investments‘ flagship Magellan fund sharply raised its holdings of Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase  in September, as it moved into bigger U.S. banks amid the worsening credit crisis.

headline: Boston Scientific Cites Lehman in Sell-Off
abstract: The bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers has taken a toll on Boston Scientific, the medical device maker, forcing the founders to sell some 13 million shares, the company said Thursday.

headline: Scuffle in Hong Kong Protest Over Lehman-Linked Products
abstract: Investors in financial products linked to collapsed U.S. investment bank Lehman Brothers scuffled with security guards at a bank in Hong Kong on Friday, as some 200 people protested in the financial district against institutions that sold the now worthless products, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Cuomo Urges Citigroup to End Executive Bonuses
abstract: The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, urged Citigroup on Monday afternoon to eliminate bonuses for its top executives after the banking company said it would cut an additional 24,000 jobs.

headline: Musical Bailout Humor
abstract: A song about the bailout.

headline: Shareholders Approve Wachovia, NatCity Deals
abstract: Wachovia‘s shareholders approved the bank’s takeover by rival Wells Fargo on Tuesday, bringing one of the largest mergers stemming from the financial crisis near to completion, Reuters reported.

headline: Keep Bailing
abstract: The bailouts keep coming, but banks are still afraid to lend to each other

headline: Redefining ‘Cities’ for the Google Phone
abstract: T-Mobile’s 3G coverage areas have proliferated — but it’s all in how you count them.

headline: Fed Adds to Its Efforts to Aid Credit Markets
abstract: For decades, Americans have considered money-market mutual funds as safe as bank accounts. On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve pledged $540 billion to make sure they really are.

headline: On Second Try, Sandbridge Promises a Revolution
abstract: Sandbridge Technologies is announcing that it has created a chip that could represent the Holy Grail of wireless computing: a processor that can perform software-defined radio with low cost and low power consumption, Venturebeat reported.

headline: The Ideal Stimulus Package
abstract: We asked a group of economists how they would like to see a $500 billion stimulus package allotted. Here’s how they responded.

headline: Bon-Ton’s Clash With CIT Said to Have a Cost
abstract: Add another retailer that has taken a blow from its creditors: Bon-Ton Stores.

headline: Citadel to Shutter Asian Some Operations, Reports Say
abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the U.S. hedge fund giant that has racked up hefty losses this year, is closing its Tokyo office and its Asia principal investment operations by the end of this year, according to press reports.

headline: Peter Orszag: An Overview
abstract: A look at President-elect Obama’s likely director of the Office of Management and Budget.

headline: A ‘Big Three’ Failure and U.S. Auto Making
abstract: A contraction of the Detroit companies would mean the end of the American industrial base, some argue. That’s not necessarily so.

headline: Phones Play Dress-Up
abstract: At least two phone-case manufacturers are making dressy fabric models for the holidays.

headline: Is a Sale on Citigroup’s Mind?
abstract: Will Citigroup, after losing more than one-quarter of its market value on growing worries over whether it has enough capital to withstand billions of dollars of potential losses, raise the for-sale-sign?

headline: Morning Clips: CW’s Sunday, New Seasons for ‘Entourage’ and ‘Sons of Anarchy’
abstract: Vince Chase, Ari Gold and co. have more work to do: HBO’s Hollywood comedy “Entourage” will continue for a sixth season.

headline: Detroit Bailout Is to Bring On U.S. Oversight
abstract: Congressional Democrats were drafting legislation Sunday for tight government control of the crippled American auto industry, including the possible creation of an oversight board made up of five cabinet secretaries and the head of the Environmental Protection Agency and led by an independent chairman or “car czar,” The New York Times’s David M. Herszenhorn and Jackie Calmes reported.

headline: More Bad News for Retailers, but Maybe Some Deals
abstract: Retailers in the United States have had a tough 2008 as consumer spending came to a screeching halt. But 2009 isn’t looking any better. In fact, most retail experts and economists predict that it will probably be worse.

headline: Ackman Raises Stake in General Growth
abstract: William Ackman, the hedge fund manager who runs Pershing Square Capital Management, has raised the stakes in his bet on mall owner General Growth Properties.

headline: Bringing That Quirky Video Store Clerk to the Web
abstract: Clerk Dogs, a Web start-up, offers a movie recommendation engine created by video store clerks.

headline: E.U. Official Clears Alitalia Rescue Plan
abstract: The European Union’s transport chief says he approves the proposed takeover of bankrupt Alitalia airline but insists it must repay a 300 million-euro ($380 million) rescue loan to the Italian state, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Hedge Funds Jump Into the Lending Breach
abstract: An unprecedented cash crunch is choking the ability of banks to lend and creating an opportunity for hedge funds to launch, or ramp up corporate lending facilities, Reuters reports.

headline: Autoworkers Worry More Givebacks Are in Store
abstract: Two years ago, Ron Gettelfinger, president of the United Automobile Workers union, offered a grim prognosis for the auto industry to union members at the group’s convention in Las Vegas.

headline: A Fateful Road Trip for Detroit’s Big Three
abstract: General Motors, increasingly desperate for a federal bailout to stave off financial collapse, told Congress on Tuesday that it was willing to drastically shrink every aspect of its operations to ensure its long-term survival, The New York Times’s Bill Vlasic and David M. Herszenhorn reported.

headline: Links to Hussein Era Still Found in Iraqi Schools
abstract: An old Arab saying goes something like this: Early learning is like etching on stone.

headline: Replidyne Agrees to $40 Million Takeover
abstract: Replidyne, a struggling biotechnology firm that was exploring strategic alternatives, has agreed to be bought by privately held Cardiovascular Systems, in a $40 million all-stock deal.

headline: Dark Humor: The Boring Politician
abstract: A cartoonist’s take on all things Iraq.

headline: Doing Good While Building a Brand
abstract: A personal branding firm partners with a group of career coaches to offer free résumé reviews to displaced finance professionals.

headline: Sterling Airways to File for Bankruptcy
abstract: Icelandic-owned budget carrier Sterling Airways said it will file for bankruptcy Wednesday because of the financial meltdown.

headline: Who (if Anyone) Should Regulate Default Swaps?
abstract: As the drive to regulate credit default swaps gains momentum, three federal agencies could be heading for a “turf war” over who will oversee these derivative securities, which played a major role in the near collapse of American International Group, The Washington Post reports.

headline: Looking for Fares, and Maybe a Job
abstract: It is truly a sign of the times when M.B.A. holders are driving cabs around the streets of New York City. But James Williamson, 25, is making the most out of his new job, according to a story in Monday’s New York Post. The newspaper says he has posted his résumé on the divider behind the front seats, in the hope that one of his customers might turn out to be his next employer.

headline: The Last Days of Lehman Brothers
abstract: Richard S. Fuld Jr. was under siege in mid-July. His renowned investment bank, Lehman Brothers, was barraged with questions about whether the expanding credit crisis would engulf the bank and wipe out investors.

headline: New Adventures for Bat Boy, and His Tabloid Creator
abstract: Elvis could get a second chance at life, Bat Boy may yet outwit government scientists, and politicians’ chances of adopting alien babies just improved.

headline: Election: On BET, a Day of Celebration
abstract: BET, cable’s most prominent channel that features programs for black viewers, celebrated Senator Barack Obama’s presidential victory on Wednesday by dropping its regular schedule and saluting the country’s first African-American president-elect.

headline: Blip.fm Raises Fresh Cash, Report Says
abstract: Fuzz Artists has raised additional venture funding in support of its Blip.fm social music playlisting service, The Deal.com reported.

headline: Alliance Data Falls as Blackstone Watches
abstract: Stephen A. Schwarzman should be counting his lucky stars that his Blackstone Group was able to get out of buying the credit card processor Alliance Data Systems for $6.4 billion earlier this year.

headline: New Electronic Book Reads Like a Bargain
abstract: A new entry into the electronic book category priced cheaper than those from Sony and Amazon.

headline: A.I.G. Unit to Tap Fed’s Commercial Paper Facility
abstract: American International Group‘s aircraft leasing unit has been approved to participate in the Federal Reserve’s commercial paper funding facility, Reuters reported.

headline: Ace Greenberg’s Lament for Wall Street
abstract: “There’s no more Wall Street!”

headline: Asian Stock Markets Rebound
abstract: Asian markets were mixed Friday but rebounded from early lows amid grim profit forecasts from Toyota and other companies as well as sluggish U.S. economic data.

headline: The Economics of Gay Weddings
abstract: The social issues surrounding gay marriage aside, what are the implications of gay marriage for local, state and national economies?

headline: Why Does U.S. Health Care Cost So Much? (Part II: Indefensible Administrative Costs)
abstract: One reason the United States spends so much on health care is that the administrative overhead load is huge by international standards.

headline: Japan Plans $51 Billion in Stimulus to Economy
abstract: Japan announced a stimulus package on Thursday that includes $51 billion to help households and businesses, the boldest of several measures that officials took to try to stanch the global credit crisis, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener said.

abstract: Wachovia reported a $23.9 billion net loss for its third quarter, as the struggling bank took nearly $19 billion in goodwill impairment and $6.6 billion in charges related to potential losses on its troublesome mortgages.

abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai
abstract: FountainVest Partners, a China-focused private equity fund, was officially launched in Shanghai late last week.

headline: Honda to withdraw from F1?
abstract: Serious sources say that Honda is about to announce that it will leave Formula One before next season and sell the team. It is believed that a statement will be released by the team tomorrow morning.

headline: New Android Phones on the Fast Track
abstract: More players sign on to develop phones and apps for Google’s mobile platform.

headline: Rio Tinto Under Pressure on Asset Sales
abstract: Global miner Rio Tinto said on Wednesday it was confident it could sell billions of dollars in assets to pay down massive debt, despite concerns about a lack of buyers, a day after rival BHP Billiton dropped a bid for the firm.

headline: MediaNews Sees Bad Timing on Newspapers, Not Bad Bets
abstract: Dean Singleton expanded his newspaper empire at the worst possible time, in the worst part of the country he could have chosen, and he has been paying the price ever since in plummeting advertising and shrinking papers. Yet somehow, even in today’s adverse climate, he professes optimism, The New York Times’s Richard Perez-Pena writes.

headline: U.S. and Britain: Contrasting Bailouts
abstract: Following the lead of the United States, Britain is moving to bail out its ailing banking system, which has come under severe pressure from the global credit crisis. But there are significant differences between the British rescue plan and the American plan, which Congress passed last week.

headline: Germany’s Hypo Expects a Loss After Getting a Bailout
abstract: Hypo Real Estate Holding, the commercial lender that got a 50 billion euro bailout from the German government last month, said Wednesday it expects to report a third-quarter pretax loss of 3.1 billion euros ($3.9 billion) because of more write-downs at its Irish bank.

headline: Kazakhstan and Banks Agree $3.47 Billion Bailout Package
abstract: The government of Kazakhstan and the nation’s four largest banks have agreed terms for at least $3.47 billion in capital injections to counter the impact of the global credit crisis, the state-owned SamrukKazyna fund said on Tuesday.

headline: Vodafone Offers to Buy Sweden’s Wayfinder
abstract: The Vodafone Group , the world’s biggest mobile phone provider by sales, said Tuesday it has offered to buy Swedish wireless navigation device company Wayfinder Systems for 239 million Swedish kronor ($29 million) in cash.

headline: Macworld Loses Its Marquee Player
abstract: The Apple-centric trade show isn’t the same without its famed keynote speaker.

headline: Financial Turmoil Threatens Biotech’s Cash
abstract: So many biotechnology companies talk about “extending the runway” these days, you might think they had entered the airline business, The New York Times’s Andrew Pollack writes.

headline: Credit Suisse Uses Troubled Assets for Some Bonuses
abstract: In a new twist on the annual bonus ritual, Credit Suisse has decided to pay some of its employees this year with illiquid and troubled securities instead of the usual cash and stock, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Apple Attends to Bugs
abstract: Updates to Mac laptops address some recent glitches.

headline: …Today Wasn’t
abstract: BAGHDAD — I was supposed to go to a news conference so I woke in the morning preparing myself for it. The New York Times bureau is in the Red Zone but on the way there I passed the fortified entrance of the Green Zone, where I was supposed to go later in the day to attend the conference.

headline: Morgan Stanley, Mitsubishi Consider Merging Japanese Brokerages
abstract: Morgan Stanley and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial are considering a merger of their brokerage units in Japan, according to Japanese press reports.

headline: Ratings: ABC Leads Again With ‘Dancing’
abstract: ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” led Monday in the ratings as 18.8 million viewers tuned in to the dancing competition from 8 to 9:30 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Property Developers Latest to Look for Bailout
abstract: With a reported $530 billion of commercial mortgages coming due for refinancing in the next three years, property developers are the latest group to seek government assistance.

headline: In a Contract Dispute, Time Warner Tells Customers to Watch Online
abstract: In the midst of a contract dispute with a local broadcaster last week, Time Warner Cable did something that was until recently unthinkable: it told its customers to hook up a computer to their television and watch their favorite shows using the Internet.

headline: As Economy Weakens, Federal Reserve Officials Consider Lowering Rates
abstract: Even if Congress approves President Bush’s $700 billion rescue plan for Wall Street, top officials at the Federal Reserve believe the economy will slow down more than they had expected as recently as July.

headline: General Growth Taps Bankruptcy Counsel, Report Says
abstract: General Growth Properties, the shopping mall giant, has hired law firm Sidley Austin as bankruptcy counsel as it negotiates with lenders for more time to restructure its $27 billion debt, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Comparable Banking Crises, 1970-2007
abstract: An I.M.F. working paper compares today’s banking crisis to 42 previous banking crises from around the world, 1970 to 2007.

headline: Huntsman Finds Mystery Man at Credit Suisse
abstract: Updated at 2:10 p.m.

headline: A.M.D.’s Results Show Improvement Ahead of Split
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices, the troubled chip make gearing up for a spin-off, said on Thursday that its earnings were showing significant improvement despite the turmoil in the economy.

headline: Bidders Said to Circle Woolworths
abstract: Deloitte, the administrator of the retail and distribution businesses of British retailer Woolworths Group, has received dozens of inquiries from companies and individuals for parts of the business, according to several newspaper reports on Sunday.

headline: GMAC Files for Bank Holding Company Status
abstract: GMAC, the troubled financing company controlled by Cerberus Capital Management, said Thursday that it had applied to become a bank holding company and would seek a cash infusion under the government’s capital purchase program.

headline: Tape Painting, As Aided by the SEC
abstract: The short selling ban may have helped money managers push some share prices up dramatically in the final minutes of trading today.

headline: Introducing the Photographer’s Journal
abstract: Today Baghdad Bureau begins Photographer’s Journal, a regular feature which will showcase the work of photographers who work for The New York Times in Iraq.

headline: Yahoo Removes ‘Poison Pill’ Defense
abstract: From Miguel Helft at Bits:

headline: Alpharma and the Buyers’ Market
abstract: In a weak market, Alpharma decided on Monday to accept King Pharmaceuticals‘ unsolicited takeover bid. King will pay $37 a share in a transaction valuing Alpha’s equity at $1.6 billion.

headline: Big Board Scrambles for a Bell-Ringer
abstract: Duncan L. Niederauer needed someone to ring his bell.

headline: Dell Plans to Shed 20 Million Pounds
abstract: The computer manufacturer announces ambitious plans to recycle their product packaging.

headline: Cheerful Gloom From Mary Meeker
abstract: From Saul Hansell at Bits:

headline: Morning Roundup
abstract: Global stock prices rise and the White House looks to help General Motors and Chrysler merge.

headline: Banks Rest Easier After BCE Deal’s Demise
abstract: Earlier, DealBook reported that banks are pretty happy about the passing of the BCE deal.

headline: The Great Shrinking Economies
abstract: The revised gross domestic product report came out, and it showed that the United States economy shrank by 0.5 percent in the third quarter. How does this compare to other countries?

headline: Embarq Auction Stalls, Report Says
abstract: Efforts by Embarq to sell itself have stalled, as current market conditions have made it difficult for potential suitors to raise cash to finance a deal, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Public and Private: A View From Both Sides
abstract: Private equity has had a tough year. Some of the industry’s debt-laden deals have crashed — Linens ‘n Things and Mervyn’s are just two examples — and the credit crunch largely prevented newer deals from getting done.

headline: CIT Group Seeks to Become Bank Holding Company
abstract: The CIT Group, the century-old corporate lender, is the latest big financial institution to seek to transform itself into a bank holding company, giving the company access to the Treasury Department’s $250 billion capital-infusion program set aside for banks to stabilize the financial system.

headline: Another View: How to Save the U.S. Auto Industry
abstract: J. Ronald Trost, a leading expert on bankruptcy law, suggests a way to help the Big Three automakers:

headline: An Old (New) TV Technology Back in Play
abstract: Canon free to develop S.E.D. television technology now that a lawsuit has been dropped.

headline: Markets Move Lower in Late Trading
abstract: Once again, Wall Street held on until 3 p.m., then lost its grip.

headline: Automakers Said to Mull Bankruptcy Option to Get Bailout
abstract: General Motors and Chrysler are considering accepting a pre-arranged bankruptcy as the last-resort price of getting a multi-billion dollar government bailout, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person familiar with internal discussions.

headline: Rescue Memo to Lloyd Blankfein
abstract: To: Lloyd Blankfein, Chairman and C.E.O., Goldman SachsFrom: Jack FlackSubject: Back to the Future

headline: Banks Try New Ways to Handle Bonuses
abstract: It may be the season to be wealthy – at least on Wall Street, where banks are awarding annual bonuses despite a growing outcry over pay.

headline: G.E. Readies $12 Billion Stock Sale
abstract: General Electric, seeking to raise $12 billion from investors, may price the stock offering at a discount of as much as 9.2 percent to yesterday’s close, Bloomberg News reported, citing people with direct knowledge of the sale.

headline: Fearing Obama Taxes, Dolphins Owner Races to Sell Stake
abstract: The owner of Miami Dolphins, H. Wayne Huizenga, is hoping to seal a deal to sell as much as 45 percent of the team to Stephen Ross before a new administration is ushered in.

headline: An Online Market for Selling I.O.U.’s
abstract: From Brad Stone at Bits:

headline: The Professor’s Pop Quiz: Who Controls A.I.G.?
abstract: The terms of the government’s investment in the American International Group were released last week. After reading these terms, I have a multiple-choice question.

headline: Microsoft Promises New, Fluffier Version of Windows
abstract: Microsoft has a new version of Windows coming that’s meant to capitalize on the “cloud computing” buzz.

headline: HBOS Rejects Scottish Ex – Bank Chiefs Bid to Block Deal
abstract: HBOS, Britain’s biggest home lender, on Monday formally rejected a proposal from the former heads of Royal Bank of Scotland and Bank of Scotland to block its government-brokered takeover by Lloyds TSB.

headline: Spitzer Gets a New Job, as Online Columnist
abstract: From Sewell Chan at City Room:

headline: Why Printer Ink Costs So Much
abstract: A new study uncovers the dirty truth about the ink racket.

headline: Wachovia Limits Fund Access by Colleges, Inciting Fears
abstract: In a move suggesting how the credit crisis could disrupt American higher education, Wachovia Bank has limited the access of nearly 1,000 colleges to $9.3 billion the bank has held for them in a short-term investment fund, raising worries on some campuses about meeting payrolls and other obligations, The New York Times’s Sam Dillon and Katie Zezima reported.

headline: Mitsubishi Rayon to Buy Lucite for $1.6 Billion
abstract: The British chemicals producer Lucite International Group said Tuesday that it had agreed to be acquired by Mitsubishi Rayon of Japan for $1.6 billion.

headline: Why We Shoot Home Videos
abstract: Why do we spend hundreds of dollars on equipment to film and store our pictures and videos, without any assurance that anyone will ever want to view them?

headline: Bankers’ Bonuses Under Fire in Britain
abstract: “The day of big bonuses is over.”

headline: Dell Sees Double With Data Center in a Container
abstract: With a new system that puts a data center into shipping containers, Dell finds itself in the unusual role of demand creator.

headline: A Pre-Columbus Day Roundup
abstract: The Deal Professor offers a pre-holiday roundup on the state of play in several deals, including those involving Huntsman, Wachovia and Anheuser-Busch.

headline: New Portable Player Plays Them All
abstract: New portable multimedia device from Cowon makes movie watching a somewhat pleasant experience.

headline: British Airways in Merger Talks With Qantas
abstract: British Airways said Tuesday that it is discussing a potential merger with Qantas Airways of Australia. The deal, which it warned may not happen, would be done through a dual-listed structure, it said in a statement on its Web site.

headline: Passport Fund Fell 38% in October, Report Says
abstract: John Burbank’s Passport Capital appears to be the latest hedge fund to feel increased pain from the continuing financial turmoil. Passport’s flagship fund took a 38 percent hit in October, for a total year-to-date drop of 44 percent, The New York Post reported.

headline: Japan Plans $51 Billion in Stimulus to Economy
abstract: Japan announced a stimulus package on Thursday that includes $51 billion to help households and businesses, the boldest of several measures that officials took to try to stanch the global credit crisis, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener said.

headline: Analyst Widens Predicted Loss for Citigroup
abstract: Veteran banking analyst Richard Bove widened his fourth-quarter loss estimate for Citigroup , saying the bank may take sizable write-downs in its capital-markets operations, similar to those seen in Goldman Sachs ‘s and Morgan Stanley‘s fourth-quarter results.

headline: Insider to Head Calpers
abstract: The nation’s largest pension fund, the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, named an investment strategist, Anne Stausboll, as its chief executive on Wednesday.

headline: Lawyer’s Arrest in Canada Leaves His Firm in Chaos
abstract: Marc Stuart Dreier, a high-living New York lawyer who has a gaggle of celebrity clients and a large firm that bears his name, was released from a Canadian jail on Friday after promising to return to court to face charges that he impersonated another lawyer on Tuesday at the offices of a large Canadian pension fund, The New York Times’s Alison Leigh Cowan and William K. Rashbaum reported.

headline: Wachovia Posts $23.9 Billion 3rd-Quarter Loss
abstract: Wachovia reported a $23.9 billion net loss for its third quarter, as the struggling bank took nearly $19 billion in goodwill impairment and $6.6 billion in charges related to potential losses on its troublesome mortgages.

headline: Tesla Promised Another $40 Million, Loses Lawsuit
abstract: The electric car start-up says investors have committed $40 million to help the company out of its financial trouble.

headline: MySpace and MTV Turn Pirated Video Into Ad Dollars
abstract: MySpace says it will begin selling ads against some television clips on its site, even if they are pirated.

headline: Credit Suisse Expands Its Business in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

headline: We Made Mistakes, Fed Chairman Says
abstract: “I and others were mistaken early on in saying that the subprime crisis would be contained.”

headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai
abstract: FountainVest Partners, a China-focused private equity fund, was officially launched in Shanghai late last week.

headline: Democrats and Stocks: History Is Bullish
abstract: With the stock market taking a beating on Wednesday and Thursday, some die-hard Republicans may be tempted to blame the rout on the election of Barak Obama as president of the United States. But fears that a Democratic president necessarily spells doom for the stock market appear to be off base.

headline: Ratings: ‘Criminal Minds’ Leads the Way
abstract: “Criminal Minds” and “CSI: NY” led CBS to another victory in the ratings on Wednesday, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: D-Wave Arms ‘Smoking Gun’ Proof of Quantum Computer
abstract: A start-up asks volunteers to help it prove quantum computing is finally for real.

headline: Stephen Schwarzman’s Seven-Step Program
abstract: The next Congress is likely to put additional regulation of Wall Street high on its to-do list. Just in time for Election Day, Stephen Schwarzman, the head of private equity giant Blackstone Group, has some advice for lawmakers on how he thinks they should proceed.

headline: Canon Adds Zoom to the PowerShot SX10
abstract: The camera maker fields its latest rig in the battle for ever-more-powerful zooms on consumer cameras.

headline: Yahoo’s $36.6 Million Bill for Outside Advisers
abstract: Digging through the Yahoo earnings report that came out Tuesday afternoon, investors will discover that the Web search company paid its outside advisers a total of $36.6 million in the third quarter, in costs tied to the fallout from fending off Microsoft‘s bid to acquire all or part of Yahoo.

headline: Wells Fargo Asks Court to Void Citi’s Wachovia Deal
abstract: Wells Fargo, which has agreed to buy Wachovia, asked a federal court to void Citigroup‘s earlier agreement to buy parts of the big North Carolina lender.

headline: Vancouver’s Olympic Plans Hit a Snag
abstract: When Montreal announced that it would be the host of the 1976 Summer Olympics, Mayor Jean Drapeau promised that the Games could “no more have a deficit than a man can have a baby.” Ultimately the Games left behind about $1.5 billion in unexpected debt that was paid off only two years ago.

headline: Looking to Washington Again, So Far in Vain
abstract: As Americans await the arrival of a new administration in Washington, investors are worrying whether the financial system is again in the danger zone.

headline: Two Ways to Revamp U.S. Housing Policy
abstract: Two economists suggest two ways to improve federal housing policy — neither of which involves more subsidized lending.

headline: Apple Discounts for Black Friday
abstract: MacBooks, iMacs and iPods are all getting one-day-only discounts both online and in stores on the day after Thanksgiving.

headline: Fed Report Shows Downturn After October
abstract: The economic decline took a turn for the worse after the market shocks of October. In November, the problems only deepened, The New York Times’s Michael M. Grynbaum writes.

headline: The 12 Days of Bailouts
abstract: A cheerful song for the holidays, from YouTube.

headline: The Very Expensive Myth of Long Distance
abstract: With today’s Internet technology, there is little economic difference between the cost of a local and a long distance call.

headline: That Vudu You Do May Take Time in HD
abstract: The new Vudu movie rental box now offers 1,100 titles in high definition. But you’ll need wide pipes.

headline: S.E.C. Charges a V.C. With Fraud
abstract: Federal authorities accused William Del Biaggio III, 41, a former Silicon Valley venture capitalist and part owner of the Nashville Predators hockey team, of defrauding investors and using the money to buy his $25 million stake in the professional sports team, The New York Times’s Claire Cain Miller reported.

headline: The College Board Settles Loan Inquiry
abstract: New York officials say the College Board, the national association that writes and administers the SAT test, has resolved a two-state investigation into deceptive marketing of student loans.

headline: Legal Gymnastics, Apollo Style
abstract: First you tell the banks that they are sure to lose money if they lend it to you. Then you sue them for not making the loan.

headline: Swiss Bank Executive Indicted in U.S. Inquiry
abstract: A senior Swiss executive at the banking giant UBS has been indicted in an investigation of the bank and its offshore private-banking services for wealthy Americans, federal prosecutors said Wednesday.

headline: Bond Hearing Put Off in Madoff Case
abstract: A federal judge has delayed a bond hearing for Bernard L. Madoff, the New York trader accused of operating what may be the largest swindle in Wall Street history.

headline: Barclays Tops Analyst Ranking With Lehman Deal
abstract: The once-mighty Lehman Brothers has suffered all kinds of indignities lately, including being carved up under the watch of a bankruptcy judge. But Friday brought a posthumous coup for the firm: Its research analysts were voted the best on Wall Street for the sixth year in a row in Institutional Investor magazine’s annual survey.

headline: Devaney Avoids Art Theft, Report Says
abstract: John Devaney, whose $600 million hedge fund collapsed earlier this year, was heckled off the stage in Miami last week during an annual industry conference.

headline: Tesla Motors Zaps Another C.E.O. and Lays Off Staff
abstract: Tesla Motors announced that it will lay off employees, delay production of the Model S, and replace its chief executive.

headline: Power.com: A One-Stop Shop for Social Networkers
abstract: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: Boston Ventures’ Nascar Team in Merger Talks
abstract: Petty Enterprises, the Nascar team backed by the private equity firm Boston Ventures, is in discussions to merge its storied franchise with Gillett Evernham Motorsports, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Russia Seeks to Trade Oil for Loans From China
abstract: As credit streams from troubled Western banks dry up in the financial crisis, Russian oil companies, The New York Times’s Andrew E. Kramer writes, are negotiating multibillion-dollar loans from a more reliable source: the cash-rich Chinese government.

headline: Rein in Chief’s Pay? It’s Doable
abstract: The debate over Wall Street’s executive compensation policies isn’t going away, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in hist latest DealBook column. Whoever emerges the winner of Tuesday’s election, he says, the pressure to fix what has become a broken system is only going to increase.

headline: Sirius XM Takes $4.8 Billion Charge Related to Merger
abstract: Sirius XM Radio posted a $4.8 billion write-down of goodwill related to its acquisition of satellite radio rival XM, and said the auto industry’s “dramatic” woes have hurt subscriber growth.

headline: XP Lives!
abstract: Microsoft agrees to continue to license Windows XP at least through May.

headline: Fed to Help Buy Assets of Money Market Funds
abstract: The Federal Reserve announced Tuesday that it would help finance purchases of up to $600 billion in assets of money market mutual funds that have been hit with redemptions by investors.

headline: Electronic Arts Adds TV Executive to Board
abstract: Electronic Arts names Geraldine Laybourne to its board with an eye toward courting young women.

headline: U.S. Shares Soar After Fed’s Record Rate Cut
abstract: For Wall Street, the Federal Reserve’s aggressive move on interest rates Tuesday was the kindest cut of all, The New York Times’s Jack Healy writes.

headline: Hedge Fund Raises the Pressure on Orthofix
abstract: Ramius, the activist hedge fund, has followed through on its threat to seek the ouster of four directors of Orthofix International, a maker of orthopedic equipment.

headline: V.C. Firm Bets on Digital Shovels and Jeans
abstract: Azure Capital Partners, a San Francisco venture capital firm, aims to invest in Web companies that work behind the scenes.

headline: How MacFarlane Manages Moguldom
abstract: “The Cleveland Show,” an animated spin-off of “Family Guy” that will have its debut on Fox next fall, is an illustration of the clout wielded by Seth MacFarlane.

headline: For Kashkari, the Challenge Is Walking a Fine Line
abstract: To hear the head of the federal government’s $700 billion financial bailout plan tell it on Friday, the Bush administration’s sweeping rescue of banks and other institutions is working.

headline: Icahn Raises His Stake in Yahoo to 5.5%
abstract: In a move likely to fuel speculation over Yahoo‘s search for a new chief executive, the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has bought close to seven million additional shares of the Internet company, according to regulatory filings Friday.

headline: More Reader Feedback: Stocks
abstract: Imagining what stock-market pundits would be saying today if the bailout bill had failed

headline: Goldman Hit With Auction-Rate Securities Suit
abstract: Two customers of Goldman Sachs sued the Wall Street firm on Thursday, claiming it convinced them to keep buying risky auction rate securities when it knew the market was collapsing.

headline: Stock Futures Down After Obama Win
abstract: Stock futures were down on Wednesday, pointing to a lower open on Wall Street, as investors focused on the difficult immediate tasks facing President-elect Barack Obama.

headline: Swayze’s Best Act: Being Able to Show Up
abstract: Diagnosed less than a year ago with pancreatic cancer, the actor Patrick Swayze is defying expectations.

headline: Former E-Trade Chief Joins Buyout Firm
abstract: The former chief executive of E*Trade Financial, Mitchell Caplan, has signed on at private equity firm Aquiline Capital Partners as an executive adviser, the firm announced Tuesday.

headline: A Century of Ponzi Schemes
abstract: The sums of money may be shocking, but there’s nothing new about the time-honored swindling technique that Bernard L. Madoff is accused of using.

headline: Arts Patron Is Convicted of Securities Fraud
abstract: A federal jury in New York convicted Alberto W. Vilar of all 12 counts in his securities fraud trial on Wednesday, a final fall from grace for a man who gave millions of dollars to musical and other causes but was ostracized for falling short on his pledges, The New York Times’s Daniel J. Wakin reports.

headline: The Treasury Secretary Guessing Game (Sweet 16 Edition)
abstract: As Barack Obama prepares to become the 44th president of the United States, one of his most pressing goals early on is to name a new head of the Treasury. (The New York Times has reported that he has already been in touch with Henry M. Paulson Jr. about working together in the interim.)

headline: A Vote, and Then a Cup of Joe
abstract: First there was Joe the Plumber. Then came “Joe the Biden,” as Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. has taken to calling himself on the campaign trail. And soon from Starbucks, Joe the Reward.

headline: Kozlowski’s Conviction Is Upheld by N.Y. Court
abstract: An appeals court on Thursday upheld the criminal convictions of L. Dennis Kozlowski and Mark Swartz, Tyco International’s former chief executive and former financial chief, both of whom are serving prison terms for fraud.

headline: I Love Housing in the Springtime: Seasonality and Economic Data
abstract: An explanation of why existing home sales are reported at a “seasonally adjusted annual rate,” rather than taken as is.

abstract: The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn is not exactly thrilled that a former chief executive is considering a bid for Yahoo.

headline: Buy American, Buffett Says. He Is.
abstract: Despite the confusion caused by the market’s steep plunges and dizzying climbs over the past week, one individual appears confident that now is a time to buy.

headline: Blackstone Eyes China Property
abstract: The Blackstone Group, the U.S. private equity giant, said on Wednesday that it still aims to complete a pair of property deals in Shanghai, although a company official said valuations in China need to come down and regulations should be friendlier to foreign investors.

headline: Quick Bits: Google’s Bailout of Yahoo and More
abstract: Google may not have to bail out Yahoo, smartphones squeeze carrier profits and more.

headline: In Madoff Scandal, a Rare Moment of Truth?
abstract: That Bernard L. Madoff may have bilked $50 billion out of investors is shocking. But according to Eric Dezenhall, the head of the crisis public relations firm Dezenhall Resources, it is nowhere near as shocking as his purported confession.

headline: Polaroid Seeks Ch. 11 Protection Amid Petters Probe
abstract: Consumer electronics company Polaroid Corporation said on Thursday it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in order to facilitate its restructuring. The maker of iconic instamatic cameras said its bankruptcy was due to events at Petters Group Worldwide, which has owned the company since 2005.

headline: In Crisis, Prosecutors Put Aside Turf Wars
abstract: On Sept. 25, as the world financial crisis escalated, two of New York’s most powerful lawyers met for lunch in a restaurant near Wall Street with a name that recalled happier times: Bull Run.

headline: Weekly Ratings: ‘CSI’ Leads CBS to Victory
abstract: The season premiere of ”CSI: Crime Scene Investigation” on CBS drew nearly 23.5 million people to the screen last week.

abstract: Say goodbye to the largest leveraged buyout in history.

abstract: Should the federal government give Detroit’s Big Three a piece if the bailout pie?

headline: Audio: The Significance of the Security Pact
abstract: An audio report on the proposed security agreement for Iraq that calls for a full withdrawal of American forces from the country by the end of 2011.

abstract: Japan announced a stimulus package on Thursday that includes $51 billion to help households and businesses, the boldest of several measures that officials took to try to stanch the global credit crisis, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener said.

abstract: Veteran banking analyst Richard Bove widened his fourth-quarter loss estimate for Citigroup , saying the bank may take sizable write-downs in its capital-markets operations, similar to those seen in Goldman Sachs ‘s and Morgan Stanley‘s fourth-quarter results.

abstract: Wachovia reported a $23.9 billion net loss for its third quarter, as the struggling bank took nearly $19 billion in goodwill impairment and $6.6 billion in charges related to potential losses on its troublesome mortgages.

abstract: The electric car start-up says investors have committed $40 million to help the company out of its financial trouble.

headline: MySpace and MTV Turn Pirated Video Into Ad Dollars
abstract: MySpace says it will begin selling ads against some television clips on its site, even if they are pirated.

abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai

headline: S.E.C. Chief Says Staff Ignored Warnings on Madoff
abstract: Christopher Cox, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said Tuesday evening that he found it “deeply troubling” that the S.E.C.’s staff had ignored warnings about Bernard L. Madoff’s financial activities for years.

abstract: Venture capitalists and entrepreneurs discussed how to keep from drowning at a meeting hosted by VentureBeat.

abstract: Vice Chancellor Stephen P. Lamb ruled decisively for Huntsman in his 89-page opinion (as I predicted he would in my previous post, “Last Words From Huntsman and Hexion”).

abstract: The site, which lets visitors anonymously discuss salaries and bosses, has raised another $6.5 million.

abstract: Under pressure from banks and legislators, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued an interpretation of an accounting standard that could make it easier for banks to report smaller losses, or perhaps even profits, when they announce results for the third quarter, The New York Times’s Floyd Norris reported.

abstract: The malaise on Wall Street simply will not lift.

headline: I.R.S. to Tighten Tax Oversight of Foreign Banks
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service is tightening up its oversight of foreign banks that sell offshore services to wealthy American clients, a move intended to stem what officials have called rampant tax evasion, The New York Times’s Lynnley Browning reported.

headline: Debating the Vices and Virtues of Google
abstract: A public debate on whether Google violates its motto “Don’t be evil” moves quickly to considering whether the search company is guilty of the Seven Deadly Sins.

headline: Obama Factor Cited in Fortress Filing
abstract: Two months before he takes office, President-elect Barack Obama is clearly on Wall Street’s mind.

headline: Investment Plan for Myspace Music on Back-Burner, Report Says
abstract: Potential plans by News Corporation to bring in private equity investments in Myspace Music have been put on the back-burner, PaidContent reported.

headline: Hedge Funds Dropped 4.7% in September
abstract: Hedge funds’ losses ballooned last month when the average portfolio tumbled 4.68 percent, marking the industry’s worst monthly performance, according to new data released on Tuesday. The average hedge fund has now lost 9.41 percent this year, data released by Chicago-based performance tracking group Hedge Fund Research showed.

headline: High Anxiety About High Yield
abstract: Junk bond peddlers should have taken a vacation in November. That’s because there were no — count ’em, zero — high-yield corporate bond deals done last month on the entire planet, according to data from Thomson Reuters. That is the worst showing since March 1991, when the market for junk debt, more politely known as high yield, was in ashes.

headline: UniCredit Trading Halted Because of Rumors
abstract: The giant Italian and pan-European lender UniCredit declared Wednesday that it was well capitalized and was being damaged by market speculation as its shares were suspended from trading in Milan.

headline: Even Toyota Has Problems
abstract: Toyota’s bond rating was cut — to AA. The economy is very bad, but that is not the only reason G.M. is in trouble.

headline: Lehman’s Private Equity Stakes Draw Interest
abstract: Goldman Sachs, Coller Capital and Lexington Partners are among the potential suitors that are considering bids for Lehman Brothers Holdings‘ investments in United States and European private equity funds, Bloomberg News reported, citing people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Dell Goes Big (and Stylish)
abstract: Dell moves up to a 24-inch monitor on its premium XPS series of PCs.

headline: Snow Appears to Fall on 2 Sides of Financial Regulation
abstract: Congresswoman Betty McCollum, a Democrat from Minnesota, used her time at Thursday’s House Oversight and Government Reform hearing to attack former Treasury Secretary John Snow and his apparent contradictory view on regulation in the financial system.

headline: N.J. Puts More Cash into Struggling BlackRock Fund
abstract: New Jersey it seems, is doubling down on a struggling BlackRock hedge fund.

headline: LinkedIn Nabs $22.7 Million
abstract: LinkedIn has raised an additional $22.7 million to help insulate the steadily growing online business network from the economic storm and provide more financial flexibility.

headline: Elan’s Hedge Fund Ties Irk Some Shareholders
abstract: It’s not just slowing growth of its main product and an 80 percent stock decline in five months that have some big investors in Irish drugmaker Elan riled up.

headline: Doris Dungey, Prescient Finance Blogger, Dies at 47
abstract: The blogger Tanta, an influential voice on the mortgage collapse, died Sunday morning in Columbus, Ohio, The New York Times’s David Streitfeld reported.

headline: UBS to Unveil Middle East Private Equity Fund
abstract: Seeking to diversify its business, UBS Global Asset Management will on Monday unveil its first private equity fund to focus on the Middle East, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Ackman Says G.M. Needs to Clean Up in Bankruptcy
abstract: William Ackman, who runs the $6 billion hedge-fund firm Pershing Square Capital, has given unsolicited advice to lots of well-known companies — McDonald’s and Target, just to name two.

headline: Permira Partner Offers Grim Industry Outlook
abstract: Permira partner Charles Sherwood said at a conference that he was “pretty pessimistic” about the outlook for private equity, adding that it would take a “mathematical miracle” for private equity groups not to be forced into big writedowns on their portfolios.

headline: Saudi Prince to Raise Stake in Citigroup
abstract: Citigroup‘s shares rose in premarket trading on Thursday after a 23 percent slide the previous day, after Prince al-Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia said he planned to increase his stake in the global banking giant to 5 percent and expressed support for Citi’s leadership and strategy.

headline: Regulators Close 17th Bank This Year
abstract: Regulators on Friday shut down Freedom Bank, a small bank located in Bradenton, Fla. It was the 17th failure this year of a federally insured bank, The Associated Press said.

headline: Vietnam to Sell Stake in Lender in I.P.O.
abstract: Vietinbank, Vietnam’s state-run bank and the country’s fourth-largest lender by assets, will sell 4 percent of its total capital of 1.34 billion shares in an initial public offering late this month, the stock exchange said.

headline: Redstone Said to Sell Midway Games
abstract: Updated at 10:00 a.m.

headline: Who’s to Blame?
abstract: In the debate last night, John McCain blamed the mortgage finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac for the financial crisis.

headline: Jihadenfreude
abstract: Iraq’s Sunni insurgents have indulged themselves in a burst of schadenfreude over America’s economic woes, joining jihadi groups worldwide.

headline: Obama to Name Schapiro S.E.C. Chairman
abstract: From Jeff Zeleny on The Caucus:

headline: How ‘Wall Street’ Sequel Tripped on Reality
abstract: Stephen Schiff isn’t a trader or a banker, but he knows first-hand about the convulsions on Wall Street. He is the screenwriter who wrote was was supposed to be Gordon Gekko’s long-awaited comeback vehicle — only to have the landscape of Wall Street ripped up and rearranged in the months after his final draft was turned in.

headline: What Yahoo Really Needs Is an Editor in Chief
abstract: Instead of looking for the next Jack Welch, Yahoo would do better to find its Tina Brown or Clay Felker.

headline: Pirates of the Amazon Abandon Ship
abstract: Students who wrote a program to help Amazon shoppers download pirated copies of music and movies say their tool was a parody and an intellectual experiment.

headline: Magnetar Raises the Gates at Two Funds
abstract: Hedge funds, faced with mounting losses and investor redemptions, continue to halt further end-of-the-year withdrawals to avoid having to quickly sell their positions in a down market.

headline: PNC to Buy National City for $5.2 Billion
abstract: PNC said Friday morning it would buy National City in an all-stock transaction in valued at $5.2 billion, marking the latest step in what is widely expected to be a round of consolidation among the nation’s regional banks.

headline: Pilgrims, Luck and Bombs
abstract: Anwar Ali describes his parents’ good fortune in having won the lottery to go to the Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia this year.

headline: Nortel Shares Plummet As It Seeks Restructuring
abstract: Shares in Nortel Networks plunged 23 percent on Wednesday after reports that the long-troubled telephone equipment maker has hired advisers to assess its options, including a potential bankruptcy.

headline: A Reasonable Rant About Formatting
abstract: Why is formatting for both plain-text and HTML such a drag?

headline: Bank of New York Mellon Will Oversee Bailout Fund
abstract: Bank of New York Mellon will supervise many key aspects of Treasury’s emergency plan to aid troubled financial companies, the department said on Tuesday.

headline: Iceland Takes Control Of Biggest Bank
abstract: Iceland took control on Thursday of its biggest bank, Kaupthing, to try to shore up a teetering banking system.

headline: Ross Warns Bankruptcy Won’t Help Auto Makers
abstract: A growing number of pundits recently have been pushing the idea that a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing could help the ailing American auto industry.

headline: ‘Smackdown’ Boosts MyNetworkTV
abstract: MyNetworkTV bought a big-for-them audience when it acquired the “WWE Friday Night Smackdown” franchise.

headline: Artist/Mother, an Uneasy Marriage
abstract: A new documentary film explores the tension between being a mother and building a career as an artist.

headline: Major Indexes Fall Sharply as Economic Uncertainty Spurs Fear
abstract: Shares on Wall Street tumbled more than 4 percent on Wednesday as frightened investors wondered how long the economic slowdown would last, how deep it would cut and whether Washington could do anything to stop the bleeding, The New York Times’s Jack Healy reported.

headline: A Year of Belt-Tightening Ahead
abstract: Most corporations will be tightening technology spending in 2009, Gartner predicts.

headline: Venture Capitalist’s Megayacht Gets Clipped
abstract: Tom Perkins, the well-known venture capitalist, just took a small hit on one of his big investments — literally.

headline: Tudor Halts Withdrawals from Fund as It Plans Split
abstract: Paul Tudor Jones’s hedge fund firm Tudor Investmenthas temporarily suspended redemptions from its $10 billion BVI Global Fund, as the company splits the hedge fund into two, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Major Investor in Sun Is Getting Pushier
abstract: From Ashlee Vance at Bits:

headline: Why Do Americans Still Hate Welfare?
abstract: “Welfare” remains a charged word in the American lexicon, even though it’s rarely talked about as a political issue any more. But why?

headline: Marathon Oil Delays Spinoff Decision
abstract: Marathon Oil will not be splitting up anytime soon, marking the latest leakage from an already dry pipeline for initial public offerings. In a statement Thursday, the company said that although it thinks the break-up would add value, the matter “requires further evaluation” in light of the seesawing stock and commodities markets.

headline: One Piece of Good News
abstract: Inflation is falling fast, which will help the buying power of American families.

headline: Barry Diller on Getting Lucky
abstract: Barry Diller is feeling like one lucky fellow these days.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Mark Cuban of Insider Trading
abstract: he Securities and Exchange Commission said Monday that it had charged Mark Cuban, the billionaire Internet entrepreneur and owner of the Dallas Mavericks basketball team, with insider trading for selling 600,000 shares of an Internet search engine company.

abstract: Bernard V. Drury is a rarity on Wall Street: a hedge fund manager who is making money rather than losing it.

headline: Japan Plans $51 Billion in Stimulus to Economy

abstract: Veteran banking analyst Richard Bove widened his fourth-quarter loss estimate for Citigroup , saying the bank may take sizable write-downs in its capital-markets operations, similar to those seen in Goldman Sachs ‘s and Morgan Stanley‘s fourth-quarter results.

abstract: The nation’s largest pension fund, the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, named an investment strategist, Anne Stausboll, as its chief executive on Wednesday.

headline: Lawyer’s Arrest in Canada Leaves His Firm in Chaos
abstract: Marc Stuart Dreier, a high-living New York lawyer who has a gaggle of celebrity clients and a large firm that bears his name, was released from a Canadian jail on Friday after promising to return to court to face charges that he impersonated another lawyer on Tuesday at the offices of a large Canadian pension fund, The New York Times’s Alison Leigh Cowan and William K. Rashbaum reported.

headline: Wachovia Posts $23.9 Billion 3rd-Quarter Loss
abstract: Wachovia reported a $23.9 billion net loss for its third quarter, as the struggling bank took nearly $19 billion in goodwill impairment and $6.6 billion in charges related to potential losses on its troublesome mortgages.

headline: Tesla Promised Another $40 Million, Loses Lawsuit
abstract: The electric car start-up says investors have committed $40 million to help the company out of its financial trouble.

headline: MySpace and MTV Turn Pirated Video Into Ad Dollars
abstract: MySpace says it will begin selling ads against some television clips on its site, even if they are pirated.

headline: Credit Suisse Expands Its Business in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

headline: We Made Mistakes, Fed Chairman Says
