headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai
abstract: FountainVest Partners, a China-focused private equity fund, was officially launched in Shanghai late last week.

headline: CBS Tops Wednesday Night’s Ratings
abstract: “Criminal Minds” and “CSI: NY” dominated the television ratings race for CBS on Wednesday while premieres of ABC’s line-up on the night proved lackluster. According to Nielsen’s estimates, CBS’s “Criminal Minds” at 9 p.m. and “CSI: NY” at 10 p.m. earned the night’s largest audiences with 14.5 million and 14.7 million viewers, respectively.

headline: Our New Gadget Blog, the Pogue-o-matic and More
abstract: The Times introduces new online personal technology features, including the Gadgetwise blog and the Pogue-o-matic product guide.

headline: Doctors’ Salaries and the Cost of Health Care
abstract: A follow-up to Uwe Reinhardt’s post earlier today on what drives up the costs of heath care in the United States.

headline: Political Satires Are Ratings Winners
abstract: The ratings for NBC’s “Saturday Night Live” are up 50 percent among all viewers this season. Comedy Central’s “The Daily Show” averaged just under two million viewers for September, by far its best performance ever.

headline: Healthy Countries to Receive I.M.F. Loans
abstract: Just as the American financial crisis has gone global, so has the rescue effort, The New York Times’s Mark Landler writes.

headline: Live Blogging an Embed in Ramadi
abstract: Throughout each day I’ll provide updates on the Baghdad Bureau blog that will explore the everyday lives of American soldiers who remain stationed in a region that is maintaining a fragile calm.

headline: Richardson Relishes Role as a Closer on Big Deals
abstract: Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico has a reputation for doing whatever it takes to cajole companies to invest here in his home state, from giving movie producers his private phone number to building a special water-treatment plant for a cheese company, The New York Times’s James C. McKinley Jr. writes.

headline: France Implements $13.6 Billion Bank Aid Plan
abstract: A French government holding company carried out on Thursday a 10.5 billion euro ($13.6 billion) capital injection for the country’s six largest banks, aimed at assuring financial stability and supporting lending to the battered economy.

headline: Treasury Considers Private Capital Role In Bailout, Report Says
abstract: The Treasury Department, signaling a new phase in its $700 billion financial rescue plan, is considering requiring that firms seeking future government money raise private capital in order to qualify for public assistance, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

abstract: Two U.S. buyout shops have dropped a rebuffed bid to take over Calgary-based power generator TransAlta.

headline: Tiger Cubs Said to Get Ensnared by Sept. Chaos
abstract: The Tiger Cubs for years have been known as among the brightest of hedge fund stars. But a brutal September has left many of these scions of Julian Robertson bloodied, according to The New York Post.

abstract: As Wall Street’s bone-jarring gyrations continue, more people seem to be seeking safety in three letters: M.B.A.

headline: Obama Schmoozed Here

headline: European Banks Tally Losses Linked to Fraud
abstract: In early 2003, as word of Bernard L. Madoff’s apparent Midas touch spread among affluent Europeans and money managers, a team from Société Générale‘s investment bank in Paris was sent to New York to perform some routine due diligence.

headline: Can You Hear Me Now, Mickey Mouse?
abstract: M-I-C. Talk to Goofy on your cellphone. K-E-Y. Why? Good question.

headline: Obama Formally Unveils His Economic Team
abstract: As expected, President-elect Barack Obama formally introduced the economic team of his new administration on Monday and nominated Timothy F. Geithner as Treasury secretary.

headline: G.M. Speeds Hat in Hand to Treasury
abstract: General Motors and Chrysler want the government to help finance a merger they hope will revive their fortunes.

headline: Morgan Stanley May Trim Prime Brokerage, Report Says
abstract: Morgan Stanley is looking at scaling back its prime-brokerage operation, selling assets or buying a faltering regional bank, The New York Post reported.

abstract: Despite launching the first phone with Google’s mobile OS, T-Mobile chose Yahoo for another search application. What gives?

headline: Waxman Wants Details of How A.I.G. Is Spending Money
abstract: Representative Henry A. Waxman, the chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, asked the chief executive of American International Group on Friday for details on how the company was using two government credit lines totaling nearly $123 billion.

headline: Fuld, Callan, Gregory Said to Receive Subpoenas Amid Lehman Inquiries
abstract: Federal prosecutors from three jurisdictions have stepped up their investigations into the collapse of the investment bank Lehman Brothers, issuing at least a dozen subpoenas including to Richard S. Fuld Jr., Erin Callan and Joseph Gregory, The New York Times reported, citing people close to the matter.

headline: Murdoch Sways Former Foe on Dow Jones Deal
abstract: Nearly one year later, one of the most prominent critics of Rupert Murdoch’s takeover of Dow Jones has changed his mind. At least, for now.

headline: At G.M., the Pride Remains
abstract: At G.M., pride stayeth after the fall.

headline: Downey Financial Files For Chapter 7 Bankruptcy
abstract: Downey Financial, a large provider of mortgages that proved risky, on Tuesday filed for bankruptcy protection, four days after federal regulators seized its banking operations.

headline: Foreign Deals by Asia Companies Hit Record in 2008

abstract: Yammer, a new start-up, is like Twitter for businesses. Do workers need it, or will it add to the digital clutter?

abstract: Nine years ago, Gary Gensler played a central role in fending off tough regulation for exotic financial instruments for hedging against risk. On Thursday, President-elect Barack Obama picked him for a central role in cleaning up the wreckage that some of those instruments caused.

abstract: Updated 2:22 p.m.

headline: Emotive Buys Sennari With Help from Backers
abstract: Emotive Communications, an interactive ringtone developer, has snapped up mobile game firm Sennari Entertainment, with a little help from venture investor Mayfield Fund, which had previously invested in both start-ups.

That outpouring, called the Orange Revolution, brought fresh hopes for freedoms and for a release from the country’s Soviet past that few other former republics had ever experienced.

headline: Haier Holds Off on Bid for G.E. Unit, Report Says
abstract: Haier, the largest Chinese maker of home appliances, plans not to bid for General Electric‘s appliances unit until it sees clear signs of a market recovery in the United States, Reuters reported, citing people with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Electric Carmaker Miles Said to Be Raising $40 Million
abstract: Miles Electric Vehicles, maker of low-speed electric vehicles and a forthcoming highway-speed sedan, is in the midst of raising $40 million in Series B funds, PEHub reports.

headline: A.I.G. Said to Have Hired Burson-Marsteller

Now the troubled insurance company has turned to another high-priced endeavor, according to The New York Post: hiring the expensive public relations firm Burson-Marsteller.

headline: Earnings Reports Drive Down Shares
abstract: Falling confidence in the corporate sector sent stocks lower on Tuesday as investors digested a discouraging batch of earnings reports and a new initiative from the Federal Reserve to shore up money-market mutual funds, The New York Times’s Michael M. Grynbaum reported.

headline: Statistics on Age vs. Economic Worries
abstract: A CBS poll indicates that many young people are worried that the current financial crisis threatens the entire economy.

headline: Survey Asks: Internet Access or Sex?
abstract: A new study from Intel pits the Internet versus sex to show how important technology has become.

headline: Al Gore and the Purpose-Driven Web
abstract: Al Gore says Web 2.0 needs a higher purpose than idle chatter: fighting global warming.

abstract: In early morning trading on Monday, stocks surged as after Germany and Great Britain said they would spend billions in taxpayer dollars to bolster their respective banking sectors.

headline: Finessing a Leave of Absence

headline: New Anxiety Grips Russia’s Economy

But as sorrow has succeeded sorrow – plummeting oil prices, a 70 percent descent in stock markets here, a global credit crisis and a slow-motion bank run on this country’s private banks – Russia has had to spend its reserves faster than anybody imagined, The New York Times’s Andrew E. Kramer writes.

headline: 4 Regional Banks Say They May Seek Bailout Money
abstract: KeyCorp, U.S. Bancorp, the Regions Financial Corporation and the National City Corporation said Tuesday that they might join the government’s $250 billion plan to recapitalize banks and were considering whether to use the money to shore up capital or make acquisitions, Bloomberg News reports.

Cahill this week approached the U.S. Treasury and the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston about lending Massachusetts money under the same extraordinary terms the government is giving banks and Wall Street firms during this financial crisis, The Boston Globe reported.

abstract: Morgan Stanley is struggling to attract additional investors for an Atlantic City casino project, TheStreet.com’s Dan Freed reported.

abstract: The Securities Investor Protection Corporation announced Monday that it would be liquidating the investment firm run by Bernard L. Madoff, the trader accused of running a $50 billion Ponzi scheme, in an effort to return cash and securities to the firm’s clients.

headline: Why Facebook Likes Small Ads, Despite the Small Dollars
abstract: Facebook is experimenting with small ads that build on the site’s conventions, such as virtual gift-giving and the news feed.

headline: New ’40 Under 40’ List Shows Independent Streak
abstract: Many of Wall Street’s rising stars have been pulled down to earth this year amid the staggering gyrations in the market. But a few managed to impress the editors of Investment Dealers’ Digest enough to earn a place on the publication’s third annual “40 Under 40″ list of young financial professionals worth watching.

headline: More Bailout Humor

headline: Samsung Withdraws SanDisk Bid
abstract: The global credit turmoil and the grim outlook for economic growth claimed another victim in mergers and acquisitions on Wednesday as Samsung Electronics withdrew its $5.9 billion takeover bid for the flash memory card maker SanDisk, citing poor earnings potential at the American company and the current financial crisis, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener reported.

headline: Bankrupt Lehman Picks New Chief to Replace Fuld

headline: Ads That Soothe When Banks Are Failing

headline: A Book for Tech-Loving Women
abstract: No Starch Press puts that idea that women don’t like tech to rest with its book called “How to Be a Geek Goddess.”

headline: Hedge Fund Giants Said to Move Funds Into Cash
abstract: Steven Cohen, Israel Englander and John Paulson manage three of the biggest hedge funds around, and they’re considered some of the smartest traders anywhere.

headline: Was Lehman Loss All That Bad?
abstract: Conventional wisdom across the globe is that American authorities made a ghastly error in not saving Lehman Brothers.

headline: Daimler Sells $1.3 Billion in Bonds
abstract: Daimler, the German automaker, sold 1 billion euros ($1.27 billion) of three-year bonds on Monday, paying sharply higher interest costs than it did for a similar issuance three months ago, Reuters reported.

headline: Fulds’ Art Comes Up Short at Auction
abstract: All in all, November isn’t shaping up to be a great month in the Fuld household.

headline: Twitter Ousts Its Chief, With Nary a Tweet
abstract: From Bits: Jack Dorsey is out as chief executive at Twitter, the micro-blogging venture-backed start-up that has become famous in the tech world for a lot of buzz and little revenue.

headline: Ticketmaster to Buy Front Line, Report Says
abstract: Ticketmaster has reached an deal to buy one of the music industry’s most powerful artist-management company and install the management company’s boss at the helm of the combined company, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Couric Is Making News — With Her Work
abstract: After two years of stories about bad ratings and an uncertain future, Katie Couric is back to making news the old-fashioned way — with her work.

headline: Ally of Russian Finance Official Freed From Prison
abstract: Sergei A. Storchak, a former chief sovereign debt negotiator for Russia and a close ally of the country’s finance minister, Aleksei L. Kudrin, was released Tuesday after spending 11 months in pretrial detention in an embezzlement case viewed as having political undertones, The New York Times’s Andrew E. Kramer reported.

headline: 2 Large Hedge Funds Face Mounting Troubles, Report Says
abstract: Two large hedge funds, Highland Capital Management and TPG-Axon, have reportedly been hit by the turbulent financial conditions that continue to roil the industry as a whole.

headline: We’re All Bankers Now. So Why’s the A.T.M. Still Charging Us $2?
abstract: According to the back of the envelope calculations of The New York Times’s Clyde Haberman, each taxpayer in this country has a $1,785.71 ownership share in the banks of America.

headline: Canadian Insurer Revises Its Stance on Auto Suppliers
abstract: Export Development Canada, a government-owned lender and insurer, has stopped writing new policies to protect Canadian auto parts makers in the event of a bankruptcy filing by Chrysler, The New York Times’s Ian Austen reported.

headline: Tough Scheduling Situation for Documentary About Torture
abstract: PBS said there was no national airdate available for “Torturing Democracy,” a documentary examining the Bush administration’s detention and interrogation policies, until after President Bush leaves office.

headline: For South Korea, Trouble Without Borders
abstract: As the global financial crisis has unfolded, many South Koreans feel they are reliving a nightmare, The New York Times’s Martin Fackler writes.

headline: Google’s DoubleClick Boss Oversees Display Ads
abstract: Google named David Rosenblatt, former president of DoubleClick, as head of global display ads and promoted two others.

headline: Lawyer Charged With Huge Fraud Is Denied Bail
abstract: A prominent New York lawyer arrested this week on fraud charges ranks as “a Houdini of impersonation and false documents” who used guile, a box of cellphones and a series of phony Web sites and e-mail addresses to steal more than $380 million, a federal prosecutor said on Thursday, The New York Times’s William K. Rashbaum reports.

headline: Can Private Equity and Labor Be Friends?
abstract: Despite the recent debacle at Tribune, buyouts may not be as bad for employee morale as some may think.

headline: TV Writers Look to Economy for Cues to Future Shows
abstract: Goodbye, “Dirty Sexy Money,” hello working class comedies?

headline: Computing in the Cloud, With Suspenders
abstract: In praise of Google Docs, a free Internet-based word processing application that also allows for offline use.

headline: Wall Street Corruption
abstract: What would Sarah Palin do about Wall Street corruption?

headline: Morning Roundup
abstract: The United States continues to borrow, growth slows in China and shares rise on Wall Street.

headline: London Madoff Employees Let Go
abstract: The 28 employees of Madoff Securities International in the United Kingdom have been let go, The Telegraph reported. The paper said it was believed that all of the firm’s traders had unwound all their positions Friday morning and could not carry on doing business because all their capital belonged to Bernard Madoff and his family.

headline: Citigroup Reported to Seek New Ban on Short Sales
abstract: Citigroup is taking the short sellers to task after its stock fell more than 25 percent on Thursday. The sell-off occurred even though Prince al-Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia said he planned to increase his stake in the banking giant to 5 percent and expressed support for Citi’s leadership and strategy.

headline: High-Flying Hedge Fund Falls Back to Earth
abstract: Only 10 months ago, Remy Trafelet was so flush that he treated about 100 employees at his hedge fund to a getaway in Venice. He and his crew spent a long, luxurious weekend at the five-star Hotel Bauer, which has Murano glass chandeliers, private gondoliers and a splendid view of a 17th-century basilica.

headline: Hollywood and Silicon Valley’s Awkward Dance
abstract: Dennis Miller, a partner at Spark Capital and a former Hollywood executive, discusses how the worlds of entertainment and technology intersect.

headline: Citigroup Said in Talks to Buy Chevy Chase Bank
abstract: Citigroup is in talks to buy U.S. regional lender Chevy Chase Bank , which operates in the mid-Atlantic region, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Duff Puts Plans on Hold as Hedge Funds Suffer
abstract: Duff Capital Advisors has recently laid off dozens of its employees and is holding off on its plans to raise as much as $1.5 billion just eight months after the hedge fund firm began business, people briefed on the actions told DealBook.

headline: Fidelity Becomes Major Shareholder in Las Vegas Sands
abstract: Fidelity Investments has become a major shareholder of Las Vegas Sands, the casino operator controlled by investor Sheldon Adelson.

headline: Book Review: A Media Mogul With Relentless Moxie
abstract: Supercilious yet star-struck, is how The New York Times’s Janet Maslin describes Michael Wolff’s portrait of Rupert Murdoch, in her review of “The Man Who Owns the News”.

headline: Workers Pay for Debacle at Tribune
abstract: When Samuel Zell bought the Tribune Company, he literally mortgaged the future of Tribune’s employees, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: Blackstone, Heal Thyself
abstract: If the Blackstone Group took the advice it doles out to companies, it would probably go private, Breakingviews argues.

headline: Markets Advance in Europe and Asia
abstract: Stocks rose Monday in Europe and Asia amid hopes that the U.S. government would go ahead with a bailout of Detroit’s troubled automakers, The New York Times’s David Jolly reported.

headline: British Dispute That Blocked Wikipedia Editing Is Resolved
abstract: A standoff over a heavy-metal album cover on Wikipedia has ended.

headline: Italian Prosecutors Seek Prison Terms for Parmalat Defendents
abstract: Italian prosecutors sought a 13-year prison term for the former head of Italian food company Parmalat Monday over its 2003 collapse, one of Europe’s biggest financial scandals.

headline: Black Friday Deal: Free Phone and a Flight From T-Mobile
abstract: T-Mobile gets into the companion-airfare game with one of its latest offers.

headline: Stocks Approach Their Recent Low
abstract: They fell 5 percent today. A University of Chicago finance professor asks whether they are cheap yet.

headline: Bernanke and Paulson Head Back to the Hill
abstract: The two top salesmen for a $700 billion financial bailout are in for a grilling by Capitol Hill lawmakers just one week after the administration officially ditched the original strategy behind the rescue, The Associated Press reported.

headline: The True Price of a TV
abstract: Two magazine try to get a handle on TV reliability.

headline: Unions Express Unease Over Potential G.M.-Chrysler Deal
abstract: Among the many potential problems that would await a merger of General Motors and Chrysler is this: auto workers’ unions in the United States and Canada might oppose such a deal.

headline: Roubini’s Dismal Forecast for Hedge Funds
abstract: Nouriel Roubini, an economics professor at the Stern Business School at New York University, predicted Thursday that hundreds of hedge funds would fail and that government policy makers might need to shut financial markets for a week or more as the crisis forces investors to dump assets, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Fidelity to Cut Nearly 1,300 Jobs This Month
abstract: Fidelity Investments will cut nearly 1,300 jobs, or 2.9 percent of its staff, this month and plans more layoffs in the first three months of next year, the world’s biggest mutual fund company said on Thursday.

headline: Seagate Joins Crowd Forecasting Lower Revenue
abstract: Investors weren’t bothered when Seagate lowered its revenue forecast.

headline: If Only the S.E.C. Had Taken Madoff’s Advice
abstract: With Bernard L. Madoff’s ties to the Securities and Exchange Commission being put under a microscope this morning, we thought we would point out that, just a few years ago, Mr. Madoff was actually advising the commission.

headline: F.T.C. Clears Verzion Wireless Purchase of Alltel
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission has removed the last regulatory hurdle for Verizon Wireless‘s acquisition of the Alltel Corporation, in a deal that will create the country’s largest wireless carrier.

headline: Literary Works That Resonate With Today’s Financial Crisis
abstract: What other works of literature–whether they be Nostradamus, Shakespeare or Calvin & Hobbes–seem oddly prophetic of, or at least resonant with, today’s financial crisis?

headline: Overseen and Overheard in Iraq
abstract: Incidental wit and wisdom from Iraq.

headline: A Start-Up Helps With the Run-Up to College
abstract: Brightstorm, a Web site unveiled Tuesday, offers courses for high school students via Web video.

headline: BlueKai Nabs $10.5 Million
abstract: BlueKai, an advertising start-up that hopes to convince users to actively manage their online privacy settings and sell better intent-based advertising information based on such actively managed accounts, has raised $10.5 million in second-round funding from Battery Ventures and return investor Redpoint Ventures, GigaOm said.

headline: Japan Plans $51 Billion in Stimulus to Economy
abstract: Japan announced a stimulus package on Thursday that includes $51 billion to help households and businesses, the boldest of several measures that officials took to try to stanch the global credit crisis, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener said.

headline: Analyst Widens Predicted Loss for Citigroup
abstract: Veteran banking analyst Richard Bove widened his fourth-quarter loss estimate for Citigroup , saying the bank may take sizable write-downs in its capital-markets operations, similar to those seen in Goldman Sachs ‘s and Morgan Stanley‘s fourth-quarter results.

headline: Insider to Head Calpers
abstract: The nation’s largest pension fund, the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, named an investment strategist, Anne Stausboll, as its chief executive on Wednesday.

headline: Lawyer’s Arrest in Canada Leaves His Firm in Chaos
abstract: Marc Stuart Dreier, a high-living New York lawyer who has a gaggle of celebrity clients and a large firm that bears his name, was released from a Canadian jail on Friday after promising to return to court to face charges that he impersonated another lawyer on Tuesday at the offices of a large Canadian pension fund, The New York Times’s Alison Leigh Cowan and William K. Rashbaum reported.

headline: Wachovia Posts $23.9 Billion 3rd-Quarter Loss
abstract: Wachovia reported a $23.9 billion net loss for its third quarter, as the struggling bank took nearly $19 billion in goodwill impairment and $6.6 billion in charges related to potential losses on its troublesome mortgages.

headline: Tesla Promised Another $40 Million, Loses Lawsuit
abstract: The electric car start-up says investors have committed $40 million to help the company out of its financial trouble.

headline: MySpace and MTV Turn Pirated Video Into Ad Dollars
abstract: MySpace says it will begin selling ads against some television clips on its site, even if they are pirated.

headline: Credit Suisse Expands Its Business in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

headline: We Made Mistakes, Fed Chairman Says
abstract: “I and others were mistaken early on in saying that the subprime crisis would be contained.”

headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai
abstract: FountainVest Partners, a China-focused private equity fund, was officially launched in Shanghai late last week.

headline: Wipro’s New Strategy: Outsource Locally
abstract: Wipro, an Indian outsourcing giant, is boosting hiring in Western countries to be closer to customers.

headline: MasterCard, Visa Settle With Discover
abstract: MasterCard and Visa said they agreed to pay credit card issuer and network Discover Financial Services a total of $2.75 billion to settle a lawsuit over anti-competitive practices.

headline: Hedge Funds Fight Plan to Modify Mortgages
abstract: Washington is pushing measures to help hard-pressed homeowners, but some Wall Street investors are pushing back.

headline: Analysts See Benefits From Big Bank Deal in Brazil
abstract: Banking merger fever has spread south of the equator, with the pairing of two Brazilian financial powerhouses: Banco Itaú and Unibanco. Analysts valued the deal at 38.1 billion reals ($17.7 billion), and it creates the largest private financial conglomerate in South America.

headline: DBS of Singapore to Raise $2.76 Billion
abstract: DBS Group Holdings will seek $4 billion Singapore dollars ($2.76 billion) in a rights offering and forecast its smallest quarterly profit in three years, Bloomberg reported. Southeast Asia´s largest bank plans to issue one new share for every two held by existing investors at a 45 percent discount to its Dec. 19 closing price.

headline: Tina Brown’s Daily Beast Is Unleashed
abstract: A new Web site had its debut this week, thedailybeast.com. But with more than 180 million of the things now online by some estimates, a new one would seem like just another digital drop in an ocean of zeroes and ones. Yawn.

headline: S.E.C. Chairman Praises Fair-Value Rule
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission isn’t likely to recommend major changes to a controversial accounting rule when it delivers its report to Congress next month, judging from comments that Christopher Cox, the S.E.C.’s chairman, made Monday in a speech in Washington.

headline: Awaiting Reaction to 3rd Try at Bailout
abstract: Will the third time be the charm?

headline: ‘True Blood’ Shows Ratings Growth for HBO
abstract: “True Blood,” the HBO series about vampires that finished its first season on Sunday, has “steadily increased in stature to become the cable network’s most popular series since ‘The Sopranos’ and ‘Sex and the City.'”

headline: ABC Eyes the End For Three Series
abstract: The three series — “Pushing Daisies,” “Dirty Sexy Money” and “Eli Stone” — will finish their current episode orders.

headline: Russian Mining Tycoon Is Back on Top
abstract: At least one wealthy investor has turned his lemons into lemonade.

headline: Neighborhood Analysis: Giving Up On Going Home
abstract: Anwar J. Ali is an Iraqi employee of The New York Times in Baghdad. She has been displaced from her home in the Iraqi capital. After making two or three visits to her neighborhood, she has begun to give up on the idea of going home.

headline: Bank Of N.Y. Mellon to Cut 1, 800 Jobs
abstract: Bank of New York Mellon joined the growing list of financial firms to take the axe to its workforce in the last few weeks, announcing Thursday plans to cut 1,800 jobs, as falling equity markets reduce the assets it oversees, cutting into potential profit.

headline: Bang for Your Stimulus Buck
abstract: A discussion of why certain types of stimulus plans might be more effective dollar for dollar than others.

headline: Woolworths May Sell Retail Arm
abstract: Shares in Britain’s Woolworths Group plunged 32 percent Wednesday after the company confirmed it is considering selling its retail business, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Stocks Drop Sharply in Europe and Asia
abstract: The turmoil in global markets deepened Wednesday, as stocks fell sharply in Europe and Asia, and the euro and British pound fell to their lowest points against the dollar in years, The New York Times’s David Jolly and Bettina Wassener reported.

headline: Spitzer Faults Bailout’s Too-Big-to-Fail Approach
abstract: Eliot Spitzer, who aggressively pursued Wall Street as New York’s attorney general and was later forced to resign as the state’s governor, has a new calling as a financial commentator for Slate.

headline: Europe Moves to Tighten Control of Rating Agencies
abstract: European officials are putting the finishing touches on a draft law that is intended to prevent conflicts between credit rating agencies and their clients, The New York Times’s Stephen Castle reported.

headline: Q & A: Stop iPhone’s Spelling Helper
abstract: You just need to download and install version 2.2 of the iPhone system software and make a few tweaks.

headline: Panasonic to Buy Sanyo in $9 Billion Deal
abstract: Panasonic will acquire a rival, the Japanese electronics maker Sanyo, for up to 800 billion yen ($9 billion) through a public tender offer after top shareholders, including Goldman Sachs, agreed to the takeover, the companies said Friday.

headline: Even as Dow Soars 11%, Skeptics Lurk
abstract: A tug of war is in full swing on Wall Street and those pulling for stocks came out way ahead on Tuesday for the first time in a while, The New York Times’s Vikas Bajaj reported.

headline: Does the Democrats’ Stimulus Package Make Economic Sense?
abstract: An economist writes in support of a demand-side economic stimulus package.

headline: Shares Near 6-Year Low, With More Losses Feared
abstract: As the stock market tumbled to its lowest level in nearly six years on Wednesday, Wall Street traders and many ordinary Americans were asking the same question: Where, oh where is the bottom?

headline: Start-Up Founders: Take Your Spouse on a Date
abstract: A holiday for tech entrepreneurs’ neglected significant others.

headline: Microsoft Issues ‘Critical’ Update for its Browser
abstract: The software company’s browser, Internet Explorer, was found to have a major security flaw.

headline: Nomura Suffers Another Quarterly Loss
abstract: Nomura said Tuesday it stayed deep in the red for the third straight quarter as ongoing fallout from the global financial turmoil squeezed Japan’s biggest brokerage just as it embarked on a major overseas offensive.

headline: Three Simple Start-Ups Hoping to Change the World
abstract: Simplicity is the key to three start-ups that rate household products, make it easier to buy solar panels and stream live video from cellphones.

headline: National Lampoon Chief Charged With Securities Fraud
abstract: The chief executive of National Lampoon, Daniel S. Laikin, was charged on Monday with conspiracy and securities fraud in what prosecutors said was an attempt to raise the value of the company’s stock artificially, The New York Times’s Rita K. Farrell reported.

headline: Ratings: ‘Dancing’ Remains Dominant
abstract: ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” continued to dominate in the ratings on Monday. No other show on the night came close.

headline: Will More Disclosure from Hedge Funds Really Help?
abstract: A House of Representatives committee room was transformed into a club for billionaires for a few hours on Thursday, as five of the richest men in the world testified on the role of hedge funds in financial markets.

headline: A Requiem for Private Equity
abstract: With the collapse of the Huntsman and BCE transactions, the private equity conflagration is truly over. The wreckage left by the collapse of so many private equity deals in the past 18 months is truly remarkable. And in it are some sobering lessons for deal lawyers and dealmakers. The most prominent are the limits of contract.

headline: CBS Orders a Full Season of ‘The Mentalist’
abstract: CBS has ordered a full season of “The Mentalist,” its drama about a police consultant with “razor sharp skills of observation.”

headline: The New Ramos Injunction
abstract: If at first you don’t succeed, try, try again. Citigroup and Judge Charles E. Ramos of the New York State Supreme Court appeared to have taken that to heart late Sunday night after reaching agreement with Wachovia on a new order extending the exclusivity agreement between the two banks, despite Wachovia’s concurrent litigation in federal court.

headline: K.K.R. Names New Leader for Troubled Affiliate
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said Monday that it will appoint new leadership to oversee its asset-management businesses, including KKR Financial, a troubled debt affiliate.

headline: Nomura C.E.O. Looks for Tansformation in Lehman Deal
abstract: The head of Nomura Holdings, Japan’s biggest brokerage, is seeking nothing less than a ”new Nomura” through its purchase of parts of Lehman Brothers, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Hexion Fails to Extend Bank Lending Agreement in Court
abstract: A New York state judge ruled against Hexion Specialty Chemicals on Friday, saying that the company could not win an extension of lending agreements from its banks to finance its proposed merger with Huntsman.

headline: Sezmi, a TV 2.0 Start-Up, Cuts 20 Percent of Staff
abstract: Sezmi, an ambitious start-up trying to design a new kind of television platform, has laid off 20 percent of its staff.

headline: Obama Vows to Look for Budget Savings to Help Finance Recovery Plan
abstract: President-elect Barack Obama vowed on Tuesday to scour wasteful spending from the federal budget to help offset an investment in a huge recovery plan to jump-start the ailing economy, a pledge that he called part of his “mandate to move the country in a new direction,” The New York Times’s Jeff Zeleny reported.

headline: G.M. Talks With Chrysler Said to Intensify
abstract: Rick Wagoner is running short of time and options to save General Motors and salvage his legacy as leader of the world’s biggest automaker.

headline: Goldman’s $2.1 Billion Loss Ends Long Winning Streak
abstract: Goldman Sachs reported a $2.1 billion loss for its fourth quarter, its first quarterly loss since going public in 1999, as even the firm hailed for skillfully navigating the credit crunch proved unable to continue dodging the ongoing turmoil.

headline: Nasdaq Overlooks Rule to Help Bruised Stocks
abstract: The Nasdaq Stock Market’s decision to suspend one of its own listing rules comes as an avalanche of shares tumble below the $1 threshold, and is intended to avoid the mass delistings that followed the burst of the dot-com bubble.

headline: No Shelter in This Storm
abstract: The panic continues today, with Asian markets plunging and European ones following. As I write this, U.S. stock index futures are down sharply as well.

headline: NBC Signs Development Deal with Hilary Duff
abstract: Hilary Duff will soon become a fixture on NBC.

headline: Bank Shares Whipsawed By Volkswagen Fears
abstract: Shares of Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs Group tumbled on Tuesday on speculation the banks might be caught on the wrong side of a trade involving German automaker Volkswagen, traders said. But they erased their losses in the last hour of trading, ending the day higher.

headline: Wachovia’s Golden Deal Turns to Lead
abstract: Wachovia‘s deal to buy Golden West Financial was a textbook case of terrible timing: That much was already clear even before Wachovia

headline: SAC Capital to Allow Some Early Redemptions
abstract: SAC Capital Advisors, the $16 billion hedge fund firm run by Steven A. Cohen, has told its investors that they can remove money early from its multistrategy fund, in contrast to firms that are restricting withdrawals, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Chrysler May Face Break-Up, Report Says
abstract: Private-equity-backed Chrysler  is rapidly burning through cash and being driven to prepare for a possible break-up if it can’t clinch a merger with General Motors or get government financing needed to ride out the economic crisis, Reuters reported, citing people with knowledge of the situation.

headline: Lead Director Pins G.M.’s Hopes on Federal Rescue
abstract: The lead outside director at the General Motors Corporation said Wednesday that bankruptcy was not a “viable approach” to saving the troubled auto giant, and pinned G.M.’s hopes for survival on getting $18 billion in aid from the federal government, The New York Times’s Bill Vlasic reports from Washington.

headline: Motorola to Delay Cellphone Unit Spinoff
abstract: Motorola said Thursday it would postpone the spinoff of its mobile-phone unit, which it had expected to occur in the third quarter of 2009, citing “stresses in the financial markets,” among other reasons.

headline: Now Comes the Hard Part for Yahoo
abstract: There’s a new parlor game in Silicon Valley: guessing who will replace Jerry Yang at the helm of the troubled Internet giant Yahoo.

headline: Deposit Plan Will Cost Banks More
abstract: When banks were flush, most of them paid nothing for a golden government guarantee. Bank failures were so rare that, for a decade, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation waived most of the premiums it normally would have collected to insure bank deposits.

headline: I.B.M. Sells $3.9 Billion in Bonds
abstract: I.B.M. sold $3.9 billion in bonds on Thursday, a sign that the stalwarts of the corporate world are still finding lenders.

headline: E.D.F. and K.K.R Said To Plan Rival Bid for Constellation
abstract: Warren E. Buffet may soon have to contend with a heavy-hitting rival bidder for Constellation Energy.

headline: Buffett and Ross Said to Eye Dexia Unit
abstract: The insurance businesses of billionaire investors Warren E. Buffet and Wilbur Ross are close to buying all or part of the U.S. bond insurance unit of Dexia, Belgian business daily De Tijd reported.

headline: Markets in Europe and Asia Move Higher
abstract: Stocks rose Monday in Europe and Asia, after a new round of government actions to backstop financial institutions and as investors watched for more signs that credit markets are loosening up.

headline: Leica to Introduce Extra-Special Point-and-Shoot
abstract: The camera maker announces a special-edition titanium version of its D-LUX 4.

headline: Deal Creates Largest Ad Network for Internet Radio
abstract: Two rivals merge to create the largest advertising network for Internet radio stations.

headline: Election: For CNN, It’s Never Over
abstract: At 3 a.m., the “best political team on television” went to the bar.

headline: Time for a Rerun?
abstract: Should a new election settle the Senate standoff in Minnesota?

headline: Job Losses Hit the Tech Sector
abstract: The downturn has begun to take its toll in Silicon Valley, which until now had been spared the job losses elsewhere in the country.

headline: Japan Plans $51 Billion in Stimulus to Economy
abstract: Japan announced a stimulus package on Thursday that includes $51 billion to help households and businesses, the boldest of several measures that officials took to try to stanch the global credit crisis, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener said.

headline: Analyst Widens Predicted Loss for Citigroup
abstract: Veteran banking analyst Richard Bove widened his fourth-quarter loss estimate for Citigroup , saying the bank may take sizable write-downs in its capital-markets operations, similar to those seen in Goldman Sachs ‘s and Morgan Stanley‘s fourth-quarter results.

headline: Insider to Head Calpers
abstract: The nation’s largest pension fund, the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, named an investment strategist, Anne Stausboll, as its chief executive on Wednesday.

headline: Lawyer’s Arrest in Canada Leaves His Firm in Chaos
abstract: Marc Stuart Dreier, a high-living New York lawyer who has a gaggle of celebrity clients and a large firm that bears his name, was released from a Canadian jail on Friday after promising to return to court to face charges that he impersonated another lawyer on Tuesday at the offices of a large Canadian pension fund, The New York Times’s Alison Leigh Cowan and William K. Rashbaum reported.

headline: Wachovia Posts $23.9 Billion 3rd-Quarter Loss
abstract: Wachovia reported a $23.9 billion net loss for its third quarter, as the struggling bank took nearly $19 billion in goodwill impairment and $6.6 billion in charges related to potential losses on its troublesome mortgages.

headline: Tesla Promised Another $40 Million, Loses Lawsuit
abstract: The electric car start-up says investors have committed $40 million to help the company out of its financial trouble.

headline: MySpace and MTV Turn Pirated Video Into Ad Dollars
abstract: MySpace says it will begin selling ads against some television clips on its site, even if they are pirated.

headline: Credit Suisse Expands Its Business in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

headline: We Made Mistakes, Fed Chairman Says
abstract: “I and others were mistaken early on in saying that the subprime crisis would be contained.”

headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai
abstract: FountainVest Partners, a China-focused private equity fund, was officially launched in Shanghai late last week.

headline: Senate to Probe Bond-Ratings Firms, Report Says
abstract: A U.S. Senate subcommittee is opening a probe into causes of the global financial crisis, focusing in part on whether bond-ratings firms, driven by conflicts of interest, boosted mortgage investments which have since collapsed, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: ‘They Warned Us’
abstract: Business Week looks at the government officials — away from Washington — who tried to prevent the credit crisis.

headline: Citi Executives Said Ready to Forgo Bonuses
abstract: Citigroup‘s top executives and Robert E. Rubin, a director and senior counselor at the firm, are ready to forgo their bonuses this year as the bank reels from the effects of the financial crisis, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Google-Yahoo Ad Deal Remains in Limbo
abstract: After another week of intense discussions, the Google-Yahoo advertising partnership isn’t dead yet.

headline: HBOS Sells Two Australian Units to Commonwealth
abstract: The Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the nation’s biggest provider of mortgages, agreed to buy Australian units from HBOS, the British bank, for 2.1 billion Australian dollars ($1.5 billion), as HBOS sells assets amid the global credit crisis.

headline: Britain Takes a Different Route to Rescue Its Banks
abstract: In a bold move to restore confidence, Britain announced an unprecedented 50 billion pound government lifeline for the nation’s banks Wednesday that it hailed as a quicker solution to the credit crisis than a $700 billion American plan to buy impaired mortgage assets from troubled financial institutions.

headline: BCE Files Suit Against Buyout Consortium
abstract: BCE, seeking a 1.2 billion Canadian dollar ($1.01 billion) breakup fee, has filed suit against the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan and private equity firms, accusing the consortium of withdrawing from its planned takeover prematurely.

headline: Yahoo Loses Top Media Executive
abstract: Two more executives leave Yahoo, including Scott Moore, the senior vice president in charge of the company’s media group.

headline: Trust Digital Rings In $14.5 Million
abstract: As more and more people move their work data onto their mobile phones, a company called Trust Digital has raised another $14.5 million to help manage that process, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Microsoft Offers Improvements for Vista
abstract: Microsoft is ready to fix other problems with Vista with its second “service pack” upgrade.

headline: Ratings: Final Innings of World Series Draw Nearly 20 Million Viewers
abstract: The Philadelphia Phillies’ second World Series title in its 125-year history proved to be a major boost for Fox in the ratings on Wednesday.

headline: Kerkorian’s Ford Exit Sparks Fear of Failures at Big Three
abstract: One of the biggest boosters of the American auto industry said Tuesday that he was bailing out of his large stake in the Ford Motor Company – a stinging no-confidence vote that raised the anxiety level in this city over the deepening troubles of the Big Three car companies, The New York Times’s Bill Vlasic writes.

headline: Game Night for Fox
abstract: Fox takes advantage of late-running football game to get a lift in the Sunday night ratings.

headline: Amazon.com Tries User-Generated Public Relations
abstract: Who do you trust more for holiday gift tips: Amazon.com employees or customers who get free trips and merchandise?

headline: What the Polls Say…
abstract: What do Americans think is at the root of the financial crisis?

headline: In Madoff Scandal, Jews Feel an Acute Betrayal

headline: Greece: Dockworkers Protest Against Chinese President
abstract: Greek dockworkers staged a 24-hour strike and rallied against visiting President Hu Jintao of China on Tuesday, protesting a port deal that cedes management control of Greece’s biggest and busiest port to the Chinese container giant Cosco Pacific Ltd. Waving placards and shouting slogans, hundreds of dockworkers took to the streets but were then blocked by police from storming the signing ceremony at the prime minister’s residence. Under the $1 billion deal, Cosco will receive a 35-year concession to manage two container wharfs at Piraeus, one of the 10 largest ports in Europe. Greek dockworkers have long resisted privatization of container terminals, arguing also that an influx of inexpensive Chinese goods will hurt the local market. Cooperation between Greece and China reached a zenith in the buildup to the Beijing Olympics earlier this year.

headline: Editor’s Note
abstract: An article on Dec. 16 about Richard Falk, a Princeton University emeritus professor of international law who has also been an investigator of Palestinian human rights for the United Nations, reported that Israeli authorities had refused entry to him two days earlier when he tried to fly in from Geneva. They said he was unwelcome because of what they called his hostile position toward Israel and put him on a flight back to Geneva the next day. Mr. Falk could not be reached before publication to defend himself. Given Professor Falk’s initial unavailability, The Times tried unsuccessfully to get comment from United Nations officials in Jerusalem and Geneva before the article was printed, but did not try as it should have done to reach United Nations officials in New York. A spokesman for the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, Rupert Colville, had said in a press release that Mr. Falk “should have been allowed to transit Israel to the Palestinian territories to do his job.” Professor Falk said last week that he was not hostile to Israel, but critical of its occupation policy.

headline: Tesla Promised Another $40 Million, Loses Lawsuit
abstract: The electric car start-up says investors have committed $40 million to help the company out of its financial trouble.

headline: MySpace and MTV Turn Pirated Video Into Ad Dollars
abstract: MySpace says it will begin selling ads against some television clips on its site, even if they are pirated.

headline: Credit Suisse Expands Its Business in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

headline: We Made Mistakes, Fed Chairman Says
abstract: “I and others were mistaken early on in saying that the subprime crisis would be contained.”

headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai
abstract: FountainVest Partners, a China-focused private equity fund, was officially launched in Shanghai late last week.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: Treasury’s schedule of financing this week.

headline: All the Social Networks, Together on Your Smartphone
abstract: Cellular networks are putting Facebook, Twitter and MySpace in one place, in your pocket.

headline: Korea Aims to End Stigma of Adoption and Stop ‘Exporting’ Babies

headline: Kosovo: Demonstrators Protest U.N. Plan
abstract: Several thousand demonstrators took to the streets to protest the planned deployment of a European Union judicial mission that many ethnic Albanians fear will partition the new country.

headline: The Freedom Recovery Plan: Daniel Alpert Responds
abstract: Daniel Alpert’s plan to help homeowners with impaired mortgages, which was the subject of my column on Saturday, received many thoughtful comments. Many readers were as enthusiastic about his plan as I was, but many others raised objections that deserve to be addressed. I asked Mr. Alpert to respond to the critics. Here is what he wrote:I greatly appreciate all the comments and e-mails I received this weekend about the Freedom Recovery Plan (FRP). They reflect considerable thought and attention from respondents from all over the country. It is clear that this is a subject that resonates profoundly and with great emotion. For those who are just coming to this debate now, you can read my detailed description of the plan here. (It’s the document on the bottom right.)

headline: Mexico: Guns, Cash and a Tiara
abstract: The career of an international beauty queen may have come to an abrupt end on Tuesday when the police announced that she had been arrested in suburban Guadalajara in a Toyota Cruiser stuffed with guns and cash. Laura Zúñiga Huizar, 23, winner of her home state’s Miss Sinaloa contest, placed third in Mexico’s national contest in September and won a Latin America-wide pageant, above, in Bolivia in October. The Jalisco State Police said they arrested Ms. Zúñiga and seven men late Monday, and seized two assault rifles, three smaller guns, ammunition and more than $53,000 in cash. They said one of the men was a leader of the Juárez drug cartel. Mexican pageant officials said they would await the results of an investigation before deciding whether to strip her of her crown.

abstract: Time Warner named Jeffrey L. Bewkes, its chief executive, to the additional role of chairman, in line with a succession plan outlined by the current chairman earlier this year.

headline: Middle East Negotiators Press Pursuit of a 2-State Solution
abstract: Middle East peace mediators reaffirmed their backing for Israeli-Palestinian efforts toward a two-state solution, but shed no light on their political progress after a year of negotiations.

headline: G.M.’s Troubles Stir Question of Bankruptcy vs. a Bailout
abstract: General Motors, with dire warnings, is seeking a bailout, but skeptics point to the benefits of bankruptcy, which can offer a new start.

headline: Law Firms Feel Strain of Layoffs and Cutbacks
abstract: Some established firms have collapsed outright, others are laying off by the hundreds, and others still are seeking mergers with larger firms to try and weather the storm.

headline: African Leaders Act to Defuse Conflict in Congo
abstract: The Southern African Development Community called for a cease-fire and safe supply corridors in eastern Congo.

headline: Investigators Said to Take Closer Look at Lehman
abstract: People close to the investigations say prosecutors are examining events leading to the investment bank’s collapse and subsequent bankruptcy filing.

headline: Aid Worker Killed in Afghan Capital
abstract: Gunmen shot dead an aid worker in Kabul while five children and two German soldiers were killed by a suicide bomber in a northern province.

headline: Parents of Schoolchildren Killed in China Quake Confirm Lawsuit
abstract: Parents of 127 children killed in the collapse of an elementary school during the May earthquake that devastated western China have filed suit against government officials.

headline: Checked at the Gate, a Carry-On Is Vulnerable
abstract: Now that it can cost money to check a bag, more people are carrying on things they used to check. But sometimes there’s no room, and important items must move into the belly of the plane.

headline: Amos E. Joel Jr., Cellphone Pioneer, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Joel was perhaps best known for a 1972 patent that allows a cellphone user to make an uninterrupted call while moving from one cell region to another.

headline: U.S. Transition Hampers Talks on Climate Change
abstract: The anticipation of Barack Obama’s presidency has left a critical meeting on a new climate treaty in a bit of limbo.

headline: ‘Meet the Press’ Changes, and Hopes Its Rank Won’t
abstract: As David Gregory assumes the leadership of “Meet the Press,” NBC’s competitors have the chance to alter the dynamics of Sunday morning talk.

headline: Ossetians Tighten Hold on Village
abstract: South Ossetian forces on Sunday began reinforcing a border in the village of Perevi, an ethnically Georgian area that has been absorbed into South Ossetian territory.

headline: Tops in 2008: Better Designs for Battling Doomsday
abstract: Our top 10 list for gamers — sorry Crisis Core: Final Fantasy VII, Penumbra: Black Plague and Lock’s Quest — you didn’t make it.

headline: European Tram Makers to Gain From U.S. Streetcar Push
abstract: As gas prices soared and dozens of North American communities sought to reintroduce electric streetcars as an alternative to diesel buses, Europe’s tram builders were some of the biggest beneficiaries.

headline: Islamic Revival Tests Bosnia’s Secular Cast
abstract: Islam is making a comeback in Bosnia, where religious and national identities have long been fused.

headline: U.S. Is Said to Be Urging New Mergers in Banking
abstract: The Treasury Department reportedly hopes to steer some of the $250 billion rescue to banks willing to buy rivals.

headline: Yahoo Limits Retention of Search Data
abstract: Yahoo said it would limit to 90 days the time it holds personal information related to searches to address privacy concerns.

headline: Top Negotiators for China and Taiwan Meet
abstract: The talks over transportation and economic issues signal a further warming of relations between the two governments.

headline: Iceland, in a Precarious Position, Takes Drastic Steps to Right Itself
abstract: In addition to seeking a $5.5 billion loan from Russia, Iceland pegged its currency to an index and took control of one of its largest banks as it struggled to keep its economy afloat.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
abstract: The State of the Art column on Thursday, about a new Panasonic technology that allows compact cameras to take higher-quality pictures, misstated the weight of the company’s DMC-G1 camera, the first to use the new format. It weighs about 13.5 ounces, not 8 ounces.

headline: Indian Navy Says It Sank Pirate Ship
abstract: The Indian Navy said it battled would-be hijackers in the Gulf of Aden, sinking one vessel and forcing the pirates to abandon another.

headline: Oman: Owner Says Trawler, Not Pirate Ship, Was Sunk
abstract: A suspected pirate ship that was sunk last week by the Indian Navy in the Gulf of Aden appears actually to have been a Thai fishing trawler, according to CNN, citing the ship’s owner.

headline: Britain Offers $30 Billion Stimulus Plan
abstract: The government plans to cut taxes and increase public spending despite a budget deficit that was among the largest of any developed nation.

headline: TV Broadcast of an Assisted Suicide Intensifies a Contentious Debate in Britain
abstract: Broadcast on Sky Television, the film, “Right to Die?” is said to be the first broadcast on British television of the moment of death in a voluntary euthanasia case.

headline: Sandy Ruby, Co-Founder of Tech Hifi, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Ruby was a mathematician turned entrepreneur who co-founded a business in a dorm room and built it into Tech Hifi, a popular electronics retailer.

headline: Where Is Leno Going? To Prime Time, on NBC
abstract: The network is expected to announce that it will give Jay Leno the 10 p.m. time period each weeknight for a show.

headline: Japan: Bank Invests in Money Manager
abstract: The Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group will take a 9.9 percent stake in Aberdeen Asset Management and distribute the company’s products in Japan.

headline: Citadel Projects Calm; Call to Merge the Regulators
abstract: The hedge fund’s chief executive delivered a strong case for calm Friday, and the arguments behind combining the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

headline: Company at Core of China’s Milk Scandal Is Declared Bankrupt
abstract: The dairy company is being sued by parents hoping to be paid compensation for the illnesses or deaths of their children.

headline: A Life Insurer Projects Calm During the Storm
abstract: Edward J. Zore of Northwestern Mutual discusses the changes that might be afoot in the insurance industry.

headline: Pakistani Leader Repeats a Long Debunked Hoax
abstract: In a recent interview, President Asif Ali Zardari seems to believe a hoax alleging that Oliver L. North warned of the dangers posed by Osama bin Laden 20 years ago.

headline: Abductors Take Brother of an Afghan Official
abstract: The kidnapping of the brother of the Afghan finance minister is the second kidnapping of a prominent Afghan in Pakistan in the past two months.

headline: Book Publishers Take Leaps Into Digital
abstract: Book publishers are exploring new ways to sell books in digital form.

headline: Plan to Deepen Economic Ties Between India and Pakistan Is on Hold
abstract: On a long road of rivalry and reconciliation, how long the current tension will last or where it will lead is unclear.

headline: Argentina Nationalizes $30 Billion in Private Pensions
abstract: The government of President Cristina Fernandez said that it had to protect retirees amid the global financial crisis. But her political opponents called it a scramble for cash to prop up tax revenue.

headline: Land Scandal Threatens Greek Leader
abstract: Two government officials have already resigned over the dealings, in which a wealthy monastery traded cheap tracts of property for prime public real estate.

headline: Attack on Pakistan Police Station Kills 4
abstract: Four security officials were killed and 26 wounded in an attack on a police station in the troubled northern Swat region, a senior police official said.

headline: Followers of Shiite Cleric Reject Iraq Security Pact
abstract: One influential Shiite group, the Sadrists, remained steadfast in rejecting Washington’s latest counteroffer in the long-fought security agreement.

headline: Nobel Winner Says Support for Kosovo Will Grow
abstract: Finland’s former president, Martti Ahtisaari, who is scheduled to receive the Nobel Peace Price, tried to bolster support for Kosovo’s claim to independence.

headline: Canada Cuts Key Rate and Signals That More Cuts Are Likely
abstract: The Bank of Canada reduced its key lending rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 2.25 percent on Tuesday, and indicated that further reductions were likely.

headline: Trade’s Lubricant Growing Costlier
abstract: The credit crisis is affecting the cost — and the ability — of importers to find trade finance.

headline: Facebook Aims to Extend Its Reach Across the Web
abstract: With Facebook Connect, users can log onto a variety of sites and see their friends’ activities there.

headline: Cruise Boat Runs Aground Off Antarctica
abstract: An Argentine-registered vessel carrying 82 passengers and 40 crew members suffered a puncture in two diesel fuel tanks.

headline: Japan Plans $51 Billion in Stimulus to Economy
abstract: Japan announced a stimulus package on Thursday that includes $51 billion to help households and businesses, the boldest of several measures that officials took to try to stanch the global credit crisis, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener said.

headline: Analyst Widens Predicted Loss for Citigroup
abstract: Veteran banking analyst Richard Bove widened his fourth-quarter loss estimate for Citigroup , saying the bank may take sizable write-downs in its capital-markets operations, similar to those seen in Goldman Sachs ‘s and Morgan Stanley‘s fourth-quarter results.

headline: Insider to Head Calpers
abstract: The nation’s largest pension fund, the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, named an investment strategist, Anne Stausboll, as its chief executive on Wednesday.

headline: Lawyer’s Arrest in Canada Leaves His Firm in Chaos
abstract: Marc Stuart Dreier, a high-living New York lawyer who has a gaggle of celebrity clients and a large firm that bears his name, was released from a Canadian jail on Friday after promising to return to court to face charges that he impersonated another lawyer on Tuesday at the offices of a large Canadian pension fund, The New York Times’s Alison Leigh Cowan and William K. Rashbaum reported.

headline: Wachovia Posts $23.9 Billion 3rd-Quarter Loss
abstract: Wachovia reported a $23.9 billion net loss for its third quarter, as the struggling bank took nearly $19 billion in goodwill impairment and $6.6 billion in charges related to potential losses on its troublesome mortgages.

headline: Tesla Promised Another $40 Million, Loses Lawsuit
abstract: The electric car start-up says investors have committed $40 million to help the company out of its financial trouble.

headline: MySpace and MTV Turn Pirated Video Into Ad Dollars
abstract: MySpace says it will begin selling ads against some television clips on its site, even if they are pirated.

headline: Credit Suisse Expands Its Business in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

headline: We Made Mistakes, Fed Chairman Says
abstract: “I and others were mistaken early on in saying that the subprime crisis would be contained.”

headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai
abstract: FountainVest Partners, a China-focused private equity fund, was officially launched in Shanghai late last week.

headline: In Era of Blog Sniping, Companies Shoot First
abstract: Silicon Valley companies are now feeling pressured to break news about layoffs on their own blogs to better control the message.

headline: Bush Affirms Commitment to Afghanistan
abstract: President Bush made a surprise visit to Afghanistan and warned that while violence could continue to rise, the United States could not walk away from the conflict.

headline: Blast Kills 16 Afghans Near Pakistan Border
abstract: A suicide bombing on Sunday killed at least 16, including 13 schoolchildren, and wounded 53 in Khost Province near the border with Pakistan, local officials said.

headline: Mexico: Gunmen Kill Reporter
abstract: A veteran crime reporter in the border city of Ciudad Juárez was fatally shot as he left his home on Thursday morning, according to the authorities and news reports.

headline: Israel Prepares to Indict Its Premier in Double-Billing
abstract: Israel’s attorney general is preparing to charge the prime minister, Ehud Olmert, with crimes including fraud and breach of trust over accusations of double-billing for flights.

abstract: G.M., like other American automakers, tied its fortunes to the S.U.V., a product line that may be the industry’s undoing.

headline: Dubai, the Glittering Emirate, Revisited
abstract: In “Dubai,” Christopher M. Davidson nicely lays out this flashy emirate’s astonishing ascent from tiny fishing and pearling village to global hub.

headline: Cash Flow From Tajik Migrants Stalls
abstract: Countries like Tajikistan that have come to depend on remittances are feeling the effects of the global financial crisis.

headline: Sharing a 3G Connection With Wi-Fi Devices
abstract: MiFi from Novatel, a portable wireless router, has GPS ability, file storage and a Linux-based operating system.

headline: Madoff Spotlight Turns to Role of Offshore Funds
abstract: Offshore investment funds used as tax havens are being investigated as part of the Madoff fraud case.

headline: Rift Unsettles South Africa’s Top Party
abstract: A well-known stalwart of the governing African National Congress took steps to break with the party and start another, arguing that the A.N.C. had turned its back on democracy.

headline: Wal-Mart Employee Trampled to Death
abstract: A crush of shoppers tore down the front doors and thronged into a store in suburban New York, killing a temporary employee.

headline: Israel Reminds Foes That It Has Teeth
abstract: Israel’s military operation in Gaza aims to expunge the ghost of its flawed 2006 war in Lebanon and re-establish its deterrence.

headline: Bangkok Airport Resumes Operations
abstract: Relief spread through Thailand as the main international airport creaked back to life after a weeklong siege by antigovernment protesters.

headline: World Markets Fall as Investors Weigh Relentless Trouble
abstract: As investors recognized that the financial crisis was not the fundamental economic problem, Asian markets stumbled heavily.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: Economic events for the week of Oct. 20, 2008.

headline: U.S. Airstrike Reported to Hit Afghan Wedding
abstract: An airstrike by United States-led forces killed 40 civilians and wounded 28 others, officials said.

headline: New Rules in Iraq Add Police Work to Troops’ Jobs
abstract: After Jan. 1, American soldiers will be required to secure arrest warrants in order to detain Iraqi citizens.

headline: Firm Offers $540 Million Toward Deal in Chemicals
abstract: Apollo Management offered to help close the $6.5 billion merger between its subsidiary, Hexion Specialty Chemicals, and a rival chemical maker, the Huntsman Corporation.

headline: Shedding Light on a Mainstay of the Holidays
abstract: People have long used candles to bring warmth into their lives and are especially important during the holidays.

headline: Thai Protesters Maintain Airport Blockades
abstract: Protesters in Bangkok girded themselves for clashes with police as the government vowed to end two airport sieges.

headline: Militants in Pakistan Destroy NATO Trucks
abstract: The attack on more than 100 trucks carrying supplies for U.S. troops was the third attack in less than a month.

headline: Topicality and Stunts on Tap for Leno’s Show
abstract: NBC’s plan to turn over five hours a week of prime-time to Jay Leno will have a major effect on the future of the network — and perhaps the network entertainment business itself.

headline: Hints of Discord on Land Reform in China
abstract: Chinese leaders have yet to announce details of a rural reform policy, contributing to speculation that officials are in disagreement on major aspects of the policy.

headline: GMAC Closer to Goal of Being a Bank
abstract: GMAC investors holding about $10.5 billion in bonds agreed to new terms of a debt swap, bringing the company closer to becoming a bank and getting a bailout.

headline: Nuclear Power Giant Bids for Rival
abstract: The Exelon Corporation said late Sunday that it had offered to buy NRG Energy for $6.2 billion.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
abstract: The Favorites chart on Thursday with an article about the stock market’s performance on Wednesday was published in error. The chart, which lists stocks held by the largest number of accounts at Charles Schwab, gave results from Tuesday, not Wednesday.

headline: N. Korea Vows to Exclude Japan From Nuclear Talks
abstract: North Korea vowed to ignore Japan at talks due to begin on Monday among representatives from five regional powers aimed at reviving a nuclear disarmament deal.

headline: Transactions in Decline, eBay Cuts Its Forecast
abstract: For the first time in the history of the company, eBay’s gross merchandise volume, the total sum of all transactions on the eBay Marketplace, fell.

headline: Zimbabwe: Court’s Land Ruling Defied
abstract: The government has rejected a ruling by an African regional court that ordered the return of land confiscated from 78 white farmers, the state-run newspaper The Herald said. Didymus Mutasa, the minister in charge of land reform, was quoted as saying that a tribunal empowered by the 15-nation Southern African Development Community was “daydreaming” if it thought the government would comply. That was a cold splash of reality for farmers who had been rejoicing since Friday’s judgment. President Robert Mugabe’s government seized the land of 4,600 farmers in the past decade, creating upheaval that most analysts say sent Zimbabwe’s economy into the free fall it suffers today.

headline: Uzbek Activist Sentenced to 10 Years in Drug Case
abstract: The sentencing of Solizhon Abdurakhmanov, a human rights activist, prompted calls for extended sanctions on Uzbekistan.

headline: A New Line From Apple: The Metal MacBook
abstract: Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, announced a new line of notebook computers that he said were manufactured in a new way.

headline: Nigeria: Presidential Election Upheld
abstract: The Supreme Court upheld the election of President Umaru Yar’Adua after more than a year and a half of legal battles and allegations of fraud by two opposition leaders.

headline: Iraq to Greet New Year in a Hush, Officials Say
abstract: Hotels and clubs in Baghdad were ordered to cancel their New Year’s Eve celebrations because the evening coincides with a mournful religious period for Shiites.

abstract: An activist investor, hoping for a big increase in market value, has proposed that Target sell the land underneath its stores to a new unit set up for the purpose.

abstract: The U.S. has joined an effort to block claims against Iraq stemming from Saddam Hussein’s rule.

abstract: Iceland is pitching itself as an island of bargains, especially to Americans who hold a suddenly valuable commodity: dollars.

abstract: Murat Belge, one of Turkey’s most important intellectuals, is also one of Istanbul’s most erudite tour guides.

headline: Greenland to Vote on More Independence From Denmark
abstract: The world’s largest island has been gaining more autonomy for decades but still depends on Denmark for much of its budget.

headline: A Plan to Improve Health Care and Limit Costs
abstract: Scott Serota, president and chief executive of the Blue Cross Blue Shield Association, recently discussed its new goals.

headline: Nigeria Forces Are Implicated in the Killings of Muslims

headline: China Has Sentenced 55 Over Tibet Riot in March
abstract: The Tibetans received prison sentences for their actions in the March 14 ethnic riot that engulfed Lhasa, according to a senior Chinese official.

abstract: Herbert and Marion Sandler, long viewed as model citizens of the mortgage industry, have been swept into the debate over who is to blame.

abstract: Two men were sentenced to lengthy prison terms for their role in a toxic dumping scandal that sickened tens of thousands of people in 2006.

abstract: Ukraine’s Parliament put aside weeks of political infighting to pass legislation aimed at securing an emergency loan from the International Monetary Fund.

headline: DVDs, Hollywood’s Profit Source, Are Sagging
abstract: Total DVD sales are down by about 4 percent for the year, contributing to a creeping dread in Hollywood.

headline: In Zimbabwe, Survival Lies in Scavenging
abstract: Catastrophic agricultural policies and economic collapse have left the country haunted by the half-starved.

headline: Stunned Icelanders Struggle After Economy’s Fall
abstract: The loss in Iceland after its economic collapse goes beyond the personal, shattering a proud country’s sense of itself.

headline: Es’kia Mphahlele, Chronicler of Apartheid, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Mphahlele’s 1959 memoir, “Down Second Avenue,” vividly dramatized the injustices of apartheid and became a landmark work of South African literature.

headline: Asian Stocks Follow Wall Street’s Lead
abstract: The benchmark Nikkei 225 jumped 10.4 percent right after the open, and other markets showed gains as well.

abstract: Students and teachers took to the streets of Italy for the third consecutive day to protest reforms and cutbacks by the government of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi.

headline: After a Season of Cutting, Stores Sweeten Discounts
abstract: Analysts say consumers expecting even better deals after Christmas will not be disappointed, though they should expect more “bundling” from retailers.

headline: Washington’s New Tack: Helping Home Buyers
abstract: The Treasury Department is working on a plan to boost the housing market by subsidizing 30-year home mortgages with rates as low as 4.5 percent.

headline: Open the Door and Turn on the Lights
abstract: A strong first step for President-elect Barack Obama would be to ensure that finance officials operate with more transparency.

headline: Tap Water’s Popularity Forces Pepsi to Cut Jobs
abstract: The company plans to eliminate 3,300 jobs and close as many as six plants in an attempt to cut costs and refocus efforts on stabilizing its domestic beverage business.

abstract: Talks are under way for Pope Benedict XVI to make his first visit to Israel and the Palestinian territories next year, Vatican and Israeli officials said.

abstract: After years of lying unused, a historic tunnel complex built in 1940 can be bought for $7.4 million.

abstract: Wachovia reported a $23.9 billion net loss for its third quarter, as the struggling bank took nearly $19 billion in goodwill impairment and $6.6 billion in charges related to potential losses on its troublesome mortgages.

abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai
abstract: FountainVest Partners, a China-focused private equity fund, was officially launched in Shanghai late last week.

abstract: The Chinese government confirmed that it would send naval ships to the Gulf of Aden to help in the fight against piracy there.

headline: No Death Sentence for Afghan Journalist
abstract: The defendant, 23-year-old Sayed Parwiz Kambakhsh, was instead sentenced to 20 years in jail, but the ruling raised concerns about judicial propriety in the case.

abstract: The Bush administration is examining a range of options to spur a merger between General Motors and Chrysler, government officials said.

headline: Corrections
abstract: A picture caption on Sunday with an article about funds that focus on alternative energy misstated the combined assets of two exchange-traded funds that specialize in wind power. As the article correctly noted, First Trust ISE Global Wind Energy Index fund and the PowerShares Global Wind Energy Portfolio had combined assets of $83 million, not billion.

abstract: A Russian cluster bomb was responsible for the death of the Dutch journalist Stan Storimans, in Gori, Georgia, on Aug. 12.

abstract: Damian Green’s offense seems to center on his relationship with a civil servant who offered himself as a whistle-blower on politically sensitive issues.

abstract: President Raúl Castro’s decision to visit Caracas on his first official foreign visit highlights Cuba’s continuing reliance on subsidized oil and other forms of aid from Venezuela.

abstract: Indian police said they have yet to determine what role two Indians arrested on Friday might have played in aiding militants in the three-day siege of Mumbai.

headline: Financial Crisis Provides Fertile Ground for Boom in Lawsuits
abstract: Accusations of executive excess, accounting fraud and lack of disclosure are becoming far more credible now.

abstract: Confronted by pro-government demonstrators who threw rocks and fired homemade mortars, the opposition leader Eduardo Montealegre called off a march in the capital.

abstract: Merrill Lynch’s vice chairman, Jeffrey N. Edwards, is leaving in January to pursue other interests, Gregory J. Fleming, the company’s president, said in a memorandum.

abstract: The moves come after severe contractions in the network television business as well as another fall without a new hit show for NBC’s prime-time lineup.

abstract: A primary school in Mosul was attacked with an explosive on a horse-drawn cart.

headline: American Express Plans to Trim 7,000 Jobs to Save $1.8 Billion
abstract: The credit card company said that it would cut 10 percent of its work force as part of a restructuring that is expected to save $1.8 billion in 2009.

abstract: There has always been an element of risk in the seafaring life, but with a surge in piracy off the Horn of Africa, the dangers have seldom been more glaring.

abstract: The leader of Bavaria’s conservative Christian Social Union, Erwin Huber, announced his resignation after his party suffered heavy losses in state elections.

abstract: Scientists said the F.D.A. had produced a flawed safety assessment of a chemical used for decades in baby bottles and food storage containers.

abstract: With advertising dollars flowing to Hulu, the popular online video hub, YouTube is playing catch-up.

abstract: Stephen Hawking will become the first distinguished research chair at Canada’s leading scientific trust, the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics in Waterloo, Ontario.

abstract: The old hedge fund model has flaws to fix if they are to fight another day.

abstract: Florence Hartmann was charged for discussing confidential rulings by appeals judges in a book she wrote after leaving her U.N. post.

abstract: For the second time in a little over a week, a deadly United States military raid on an Afghan house has incited protests and produced conflicting reports over who was killed.

abstract: Defendants are often abused in custody and held for months or even years before being referred to a judge, according to a report by Human Rights Watch.

abstract: The head of a new Congressional panel set up to monitor the federal bailout says the government still does not seem to have a coherent strategy for easing the crisis.
