abstract: The daughter of Donald Trump has taken to blogging about saving money on lunch.

headline: U.N. Chief and African Leaders Seek Congo Peace
abstract: An emergency summit meeting on the bloody crisis in eastern Congo began on Friday with an attempt to shore up a tenuous cease-fire.

headline: Concerned Fed Trims Key Rate by a Half Point
abstract: Even as the Fed reduced its benchmark interest rate to 1 percent, the White House was weighing a plan to slow the foreclosure epidemic in the housing market.

headline: Gaza Truce May Be Revived by Necessity
abstract: Israel and Hamas accuse each other of bad faith, and each side has a point. Rockets from Gaza never stopped entirely during the truce, and Israel kept goods from Gaza, crippling its economy.

headline: Morgan Stanley Still Vulnerable
abstract: The bank’s stock price was pushed down by rumors about the fate of a $9 billion injection by the Japanese bank Mitsubishi, illustrating how much Morgan Stanley is exposed.

headline: France: Merger Talks for Lenders
abstract: Groupe Caisse d’Epargne and Groupe Banque Populaire, the French lenders that control Natixis, are in talks to merge as the global financial crisis pushes banks to combine.

headline: In Lean Times, Online Coupons Are Catching On
abstract: The effort to find a deal in brick-and-mortar stores has moved online, where a rising world of coupon-clipping has taken shape.

headline: Britain: Official Admits Mistake in Corfu Case
abstract: George Osborne, a senior Conservative Party official, said that he had made a mistake in his dealings with a Russian billionaire in Corfu, Greece, last summer.

abstract: Preliminary negotiations could lead to a trade pact between Canada and Europe that would be even more sweeping than the North American Free Trade Agreement.

headline: Russia Seeks to Trade Oil for Loans From China

headline: Goldman Sees No Limits on Leverage, Analyst Says

Rashbaum reported.

headline: A Legal Frenzy as Banks Battle for Wachovia
abstract: A showdown between two of the nation’s largest banks over the Wachovia Corporation grew into a widening battle involving two courts and a cast including Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke and an army of bankers, lawyers and other regulators trying to resolve the fate of one of the biggest prizes to emerge from the credit crisis, The New York Times’s Eric Dash writes.

headline: Future Bits: The Revenge of Software
abstract: In cellphones, the defining moment of 2008 was Apple’s introduction of the App Store. For 2009, the top question is who can create a rival platform.

headline: Hope and Fear in Motown
abstract: Fall in Detroit has always felt a bit like spring elsewhere. It is traditionally the season of fresh starts for the hometown industry, a time when the auto companies get a jump on the calendar and begin shipping next year’s models to dealers.

headline: Two Nascar Teams to Merge
abstract: Teresa Earnhardt and Chip Ganassi will combine their sponsorship-strapped race teams next season in an effort to stabilize their organizations in a tough economic time.

headline: YouTube Pales Next to Hulu’s Spiffy Multiplex
abstract: YouTube is getting a few movies and TV shows. But it’s far easier to find and watch videos on rival sites like Hulu.com.

headline: Japan Plans $51 Billion in Stimulus to Economy
abstract: Japan announced a stimulus package on Thursday that includes $51 billion to help households and businesses, the boldest of several measures that officials took to try to stanch the global credit crisis, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener said.

headline: Analyst Widens Predicted Loss for Citigroup
abstract: Veteran banking analyst Richard Bove widened his fourth-quarter loss estimate for Citigroup , saying the bank may take sizable write-downs in its capital-markets operations, similar to those seen in Goldman Sachs ‘s and Morgan Stanley‘s fourth-quarter results.

headline: Insider to Head Calpers
abstract: The nation’s largest pension fund, the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, named an investment strategist, Anne Stausboll, as its chief executive on Wednesday.

headline: Lawyer’s Arrest in Canada Leaves His Firm in Chaos
abstract: Marc Stuart Dreier, a high-living New York lawyer who has a gaggle of celebrity clients and a large firm that bears his name, was released from a Canadian jail on Friday after promising to return to court to face charges that he impersonated another lawyer on Tuesday at the offices of a large Canadian pension fund, The New York Times’s Alison Leigh Cowan and William K. Rashbaum reported.

headline: Wachovia Posts $23.9 Billion 3rd-Quarter Loss
abstract: Wachovia reported a $23.9 billion net loss for its third quarter, as the struggling bank took nearly $19 billion in goodwill impairment and $6.6 billion in charges related to potential losses on its troublesome mortgages.

headline: Tesla Promised Another $40 Million, Loses Lawsuit
abstract: The electric car start-up says investors have committed $40 million to help the company out of its financial trouble.

headline: MySpace and MTV Turn Pirated Video Into Ad Dollars
abstract: MySpace says it will begin selling ads against some television clips on its site, even if they are pirated.

headline: Credit Suisse Expands Its Business in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Credit Suisse announced Monday that it had acquired majority ownership of Saudi Swiss Securities, which will be renamed Credit Suisse Saudi Arabia.

headline: We Made Mistakes, Fed Chairman Says
abstract: “I and others were mistaken early on in saying that the subprime crisis would be contained.”

headline: FountainVest Springs Up with New Fund in Shanghai
abstract: FountainVest Partners, a China-focused private equity fund, was officially launched in Shanghai late last week.

headline: Guy Hands Sees No Sunshine Ahead
abstract: Guy Hands, the British financier whose firm owns EMI, didn’t have any words Thursday to warm the hearts of his employees — or his rivals, for that matter.

headline: Fleecing the Gullible
abstract: Two examples of how the gullible lost out when the brokers and bankers came to call.

headline: Advantage of Corporate Bankruptcy Is Dwindling
abstract: Harsh as it is, a bankruptcy filing has always offered a glimmer of hope for a business hobbled by debt or a downturn. A company could slim down, negotiate manageable payments to workers and suppliers and keep going, preserving jobs.

headline: Fund Hurt by Volkswagen Trade to Close
abstract: JO Hambro Capital Management, which oversees about $3.5 billion in assets, is shuttering one of its two hedge funds after slamming into the surprise surge of  Volkswagenstock last month, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

headline: InBev Says Anheuser Deal Is a Go, as Results Beat Forecasts
abstract: InBev insisted on Thursday its $52 billion takeover of Anheuser-Busch was on track after third-quarter results slightly exceeded expectations despite rocketing costs.

headline: Yahoo’s Lost Year
abstract: From Saul Hansell at Bits:

headline: In Washington, Some Optimism for a Big Three Bankruptcy
abstract: In the days before Lehman Brothers was allowed to fail, Treasury officials made clear that they did not think the investment bank’s collapse would have a major ripple effect.

headline: Why We Should Let Housing Prices Keep Falling
abstract: An economist offers three arguments against government intervention to prop up home values.

headline: A.I.G. Rescue Grows to $150 Billion
abstract: The Bush administration revised its rescue of the American International Group, raising the total amount to $150 billion, amid signs that the interest on its current credit line of more than $100 billion was putting too much strain on the ailing insurer.

headline: Fortress’ Ski Resort Blues
abstract: Fortress Investment Group, the troubled alternative-investment firm, may be forced to push one of its holdings — the ski resort operator Intrawest — into bankruptcy, as some of the company’s lenders refuse to restructure its debt, The New York Post reported.

headline: Each Player in Big Three to Bring Its Own Plan
abstract: The Detroit automakers have been lumped together for decades as the Big Three, and for good reason; their goals have usually been aligned.

headline: Big Three’s Troubles May Touch Financial Sector
abstract: To the long list of troubles plaguing the financial industry, add three big ones – make that Big Three ones.

headline: Election: When to Signal a Winner?
abstract: On Tuesday, all the networks (and other news organizations with their own Web sites) will be trying to strike a balance.

headline: Panasonic to Swallow Up Sanyo
abstract: Panasonic said it would acquire smaller rival Sanyo Electric, in a deal to create Japan’s top electronics maker, foreshadowing further consolidation in an industry hit by slowing consumer demand.

headline: Reach Out and Touch Someone
abstract: Television makers think that 3D could be the Next Big Thing in display technology, but are manufacturers out of their depth?

headline: To Save Money, Fox and NBC Stations Start Combining Video News Operations
abstract: In a move intended to save money in the economically pressed business of local television news, two stations in Philadelphia owned by NBC and Fox are combining some of their video operations.

headline: The ‘Gun-Show Loophole,’ Revisited
abstract: A critique of a recent study on whether gun shows affect crime rates.

headline: Mark Cuban Nabbed. So What?
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission’s decision to sue Mark Cuban, the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks, made headlines around the country. The insider trading case against Mr. Cuban shows that the “cop on the beat” is there to ensure the integrity of the markets. But is this case something we should care about?

headline: Can Anyone Solve the Securitization Problem?
abstract: So now the mortgage finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac say they are going to institute a mortgage modification program. Well, good for them. Announced this afternoon, the plan calls for struggling homeowners with mortgages held by Fannie and Freddie to have their payments reduced to 38 percent of their gross income through a combination of interest rate reductions, principle reductions and longer repayment terms. This comes on the heels of Citigroup’s announcement on Monday that it would undertake a mortgage modification program, which came on the heels of a similar announcement last week from JPMorgan Chase, which came on the heels of Countrywide’s announcement, and so on.

headline: Selloffs Pummel Blackstone and Fortress
abstract: The Blackstone Group: $5.28.

headline: On the Influence of Newspapers
abstract: Perhaps the Illinois governor’s reported attempts to force out editorial board members mean that newspapers have some persistent economic value after all.

headline: Insurers Under Pressure as Concerns About Capital Grow
abstract: The shares of several big insurance companies came under selling pressure on Tuesday after Goldman Sachs downgraded the Hartford Financial Services Group, Prudential Financial and the Principal Financial Group to “sell” ratings and warned that investment losses would force the companies to raise capital.

headline: Intel’s Barrett: Teachers Matter More Than PCs
abstract: “Where is the public outrage that the U.S. education system is failing our kids?”

headline: Go East, Young Techie
abstract: A Seattle firm has created a new site, ObamaCTO.org, for people to funnel tech policy ideas to the Obama administration.

headline: LG Electronics Joins F1
abstract: Amidst all the financial gloom, there could be a flight to quality towards F1 – to use a business term discussed in my F1 economy story last month – and signs are this is already happening. LG Electronics, “a global leader and technology innovator in consumer electronics, today announced that it has signed an agreement to become a Global Partner of Formula 1

headline: No Penalties in S.E.C.’s Pequot Case
abstract: An administrative law judge at the Securities and Exchange Commission has concluded that S.E.C. officials did not mishandle an investigation into possible insider trading by a major hedge fund, Pequot Capital Management, and that no disciplinary action should be taken against two officials involved in that inquiry, The New York Times’s Walt Bogdanich reported.

headline: Prices Falling for Online Ads
abstract: Advertisers are paying a lot less for the online ads that many Web sites depend on for revenue, according to a new survey.

headline: A Credit Card Loses Its High-Tech Cred
abstract: The Blue card from American Express once had a smart chip and card reader for home use. Now it makes you eligible for an old-fashioned day planner.

headline: Another View: Blaming the S.E.C.
abstract: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, is writing posts for The Deal Professor blog while Steven M. Davidoff is away. Mr. Henning specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and is a former editor of the White Collar Crime Law Prof Blog.

headline: TPG’s Nissin Deal Runs Into Trouble, Report Says
abstract: TPG is at risk of losing a substantial amount of money it coughed up to invest in a Chinese leasing venture after a business dispute in which local police were called in to remove the private equity firm’s representatives, The Financial Times reported, citing people familiar with the matter.
